This course is pretty easy and can be fun depending on your project group! It's more time consuming if you're not familiar with HTML˼SS/JS but the first few weeks do a decent job of catching everyone up to speed enough that anyone can confidently work on their project.
learnt so much, but lecture was not always that helpful or necessary

This course takes up much more time than I expected. There are homeworks on design concepts that take a decent amount of time and are graded pretty harshly, and there is a massive project that has many parts, all of which are also graded pretty harshly. It is extremely difficult to get an A in this class (this is a change from last year). Often your project seems like a great idea at the beginning and then becomes extremely difficult to create, and doesn’t fit with the point of the class.
I enjoyed the class, and you get the chance to teach yourself how to code on HTML, CSS and JavaScript.

They tried to make this class "harder" by giving obnoxious mandatory reading quizzes every class and grading assignments in a ridiculous manner. The lectures aren't worth going to, most of the project assignments are busywork that isn't related to interfaces, and the personal assignments are annoying. I came in with prior knowledge and learned nothing from this class- I absolutely recommend NOT TAKING this with Nell in the winter.

Once upon a time, 330 was known throughout the EECS major for being the most cartoonishly easy class in the major. When faced with how to change this, the admins/teacher decided not to add new content, but rather to simply make standards massively harsher and add a lot more assignment for a class that still has the same cartoonishly low amount of content it always did. If you are looking for an easy class, don't take this because it takes a LOT of time and is very difficult. If you're looking for a challenging class, also don't take this because it won't teach you anything despite all the challenge. Basically just avoid this dumpster fire in general. This class has gone through two incarnations, hopefully it goes through a third because it is very needed.

Class time was so poorly utilized by the professor. It would have been so much more beneficial to learn how to code in HTML and Java to optimize user experience. Instead, lectures covered things that seemed so common sense. Pretty easy though and project was fun.
Get a good group, divide work equitably--there will be many prototypes, many testings, many write-ups.

The course is not difficult but intensive. The project is focused on design interface more than the functionalities of your web application. The guidelines followed by the TAs are usually strict. But a lot t learn if interested towards learning sciences.
It helps me a lot in HCI.
Very cool class, Prof O'rourke hits all the relevant topics, the assignments are kinda tedious but everything is interesting and relevant to different parts of the human-computer interaction field
Wish there were more coding aspects of the class. Not very exciting or difficult material

I was unfortunately disappointed with this class. The assignments were very long, and short/overlapping deadlines and strict requirements meant that this course gave unnecessary stress where it wasn't needed. The group project assignments were graded unnecessarily harsh and forced groups to constantly meet up outside of class to fulfill basic requirements. Lectures were interesting but dry, and the reading quizzes didn't feel like they added to my learning. My TA took a long time to grade assignments and constantly arrived late to studio and office hours. This course really needs to place less of an emphasis on fitting so much material into a short period of time and should focus more about getting students equipped with the skills necessary to approach emerging topics in HCI. It is clear that Nell and the TAs are passionate about HCI, and I hope this class can improve for the next time.
Good class. Not too hard. I basically built our website by myself and I still wasn't overwhelmed and I still really liked the class
I was very confused about the grading rules.
I loved it! Got to learn HTML˼SS/JS although it was self-taught, the class gave me a reason to learn it

This class is known for being super easy, so while I do appreciate their efforts to make it a little more rewarding, which I didn't mind, I do think they messed up by not actually teaching us the coding languages properly. The homework that required coding was something I went into completely blind because I had never coded before, so I was annoyed that we were forced to just Google everything. I'm not paying tuition to just Google. The project requirements were fine, but the busywork wasn't helpful. And finally, those quizzes every class were the most annoying and useless thing I've ever had to do in a class. Not only do people skip class intentionally and just get the code from their friends, people just answer randomly on the questions and it just takes time up. Completely useless.
Not an interesting course for me. Much more design-focused and oriented.

Don't take it with Prof O' Rouke!!! You don't learn much, and have to put so much effort and time into your project. But, you don't get anything out of it because it is what you can do in your free time. Even grading is very harsh, so it is not worth it.

There were a lot of assignments. They're not very difficult, but the class was a lot more work than I expected. Having reading quizzes during each lecture was excessive, and not that helpful. The content of the course was very intuitive. It did not seem necessary to spend a lot of time engaging with the material.

Worst class I've taken at Northwestern. This class encompasses how much the NUCS curriculum needs to improve. O'Rourke is not a bad professor, but this course is just so badly taught. The class is called human-computer interaction, which is basically "how to build a good-looking and interactive web app." But the prof spent literally 10 minutes on HTML and CSS, and NONE on Javascript. There were 2 homework assignments that were decently difficult if you had no CSS or HTML experience. Luckily, I did, so I did not struggle too much in this class, but I would have liked to learn the cooler tips and tricks regarding CSS, HTML, Javascript, and web development in general. None of this was taught, and I can't imagine how hard it was for students who came in with no CSS, HTML experience. O'Rourke spent a whole lecture literally going over font types, sizes, and colors. What a waste. Do not take this class if you have no HTML, CSS experience; most likely you will find it quite difficult, and also they grade tough. If your margins are off like 1px, they take off 1 point (homework assignments out of 20). There are no tests which are nice, the "final" is really just building a web app prototype using HTML, CSS, and Javascript given a specific idea and purpose. At the end of the quarter, you have to give a 7-minute presentation about your web app and the problem it addresses. The whole process of building this prototype is similar to DTC, where you have to do user testing, etc. Think of this class as a jank, waste of time web development version of DTC. Wouldn't recommend.

Some take it because it teaches you 'html˼ss and javascript'. Please don't take this class for that reason. It teaches you the bare minimum of it. This class is about learning how users would interact with your product, and if you are not interested in this topic this class will bore you out of your mind. The TAs are also horrid in programming either since they are not expected to be good programmers.
I greatly enjoyed this course, the material was interesting and not extremely challenging but you could put in more work if you wanted to get as much as you can out of the class

This course got a lot harder than it used to be, and therefore it was harder than most people expected. Was a reasonable amount of work if you had a good group (make sure you have a good group, try not to be the only CS major in your group!!), was a LOT of work if you had a bad group. Grading was pretty harsh, seemed like there was an effort to make this not an easy A anymore. Which basically meant grading things really harshly to prevent as many people from getting A's, which felt unfair at times.

Great class overall. It is pretty easy but still would take quite a lot of time, as any front-end development. Students are put in groups of 4 for a quarter long project. A lot depends on your team, try to arrange responsible teammates.

The entire class is a group project in which you implement an application of your own. There is a lot of freedom, but it is a bit difficult if you've never coded in HTML˼SS before because they don't teach it in class. The TA's are pretty helpful, but there isn't a lot of time for the project so you want to make sure you're on top of your stuff. The grading is a little annoying because the TAs are only allowed to give a certain amount of each grade.

I liked how this class was structured. Also, it's very important to go into this class with friends you know won't slack off, since the entire course is based on one cumulative project. I loved my group, so I did well. Others may not have. Also, lectures were fairly useless, and I found that learning about paper prototyping was not really useful to creating a computer prototype.

Everything taught in this class can be self-learned easily. In fact, the class is set up in a way that forces you to self-learn, especially HTML˼SS and JavaScript. So ask yourself, why spend tuition money on this class? Maybe only if you want a moderately easy A (not too easy though) or if you're interested in doing an HCI project.

Good course, but bad implementation of grading. The topic of the course was easy and straightforward, and if you have a good group, the class shouldn't be difficult. However, the grading was unfair. Only 2 people from each discussion section were allowed to get an A on any given assignment (according to my TA). I wish we had spent more time on actually learning javascript. But other than that, it is a fairly easy course, its a good supplement for taking with hard classes like 213 or 212. Iɽ recommend it though! Nell was a super nice professor and I enjoyed her lectures event though sometimes the material was a little boring.
The course wasn't very involved.
TA was quite mean, which is the awful feeling all through the course
The project is really fun and interesting.

Assignments could be really time consuming, and not much direction was given for the actual computer science aspect of this course, so I would recommend being familiar with HTML˼SS/JavaScript before taking this. Grading was sometimes harsh and/or unclear because they don't want the mean to be too high.
This class has a policy of artifically curving down since only two people can get a perfect score on a single assignment per studio section. Take that as you will.
This class has gotten a LOT harder apparently. This had made the projects significantly better but don't expect an easy A.

The group is divided by studio, if you would like to have fixed partners, be careful to have same studio with each other. The course are mostly introductions for the graphic design principle for HCI, focusing on the website front end.

It's cool that you get to create your own application throughout the quarter but I felt that the teaching style and evaluation methods could be greatly improved. Your grade is based entirely on homeworks and your project checkpoints with no exams, with lectures mainly rehashing the readings, so lectures seemed pretty superfluous. Furthermore, the lecture quizzes were intended to encourage lecture attendance but because everyone had their computers out, people weren't focused on the professor and overall lectures didn't seem to add much to the class, which seems pretty counterintuitive for any class. Also, although the readings and the professor teaches concepts on design concepts, they spend very little time teaching you the actual tools (HTML, CSS, Javascript, etc.) and you're forced to self-learn ALL of it, which made the project difficult because you know what it's supposed to look like but have no instruction on how to get there or how to write efficient code. You learn nothing of Bootstrap or JQuery, which end up being extremely important for the project. I think a lot of students come into the class hoping to learn HTML, CSS, Javascript, and other tools to create websites, and the fact that we spend so much time learning the theory behind HCI but not the tools doesn't make much sense and puts at a disadvantage the students who don't have prior experience in those coding areas.
Group project is the main component of the class. Great instruction, engagement, feedback, and fair grading overall.
This course helped me learn about human centered design and design thinking. This course did not help me learn about web technologies.

Do not take this course if you want to learn HTML/ CSS/ JavaScript. I went into this course already knowing a lot about any of these topics. Everything I learned from this course about HTML/ CSS/ JavaScript was things I learned by myself for the quarter project. The course material is almost all about human centered design and design concepts. This was frustrating because there was a disconnect from the course material and the testing of our websites in discussion. There are online canvas quizzes for the readings every lecture.
The course is trivial. Every week you have to take two little quiz and complete part of the project by using HTML, CSS and Javascript. And you have to write lots of paper.

This class forces you to learn HTML/Javascript on your own because it isn't taught. That is the main part of the class and is essential for the project. The lectures did not teach you anything if you actually do the readings for the quizzes.

HCI is a super interesting subject, but that doesn't really translate well into a large lecture class, although it's evident that Nell is trying. The assignments are fine, but be wary of grade deflation. The TA's are very picky with grading.

GPA booster. This can be an interesting class, and you'll learn web dev principles. It's not as ⟪sy' as people say, and you do have to put in the hours to do well. Lectures however are just recounts of the readings, and were not informative at all for the most part, and reading quizzes in lecture means you still have to attend. Interesting content, but not the best taught course at NU.
Not bad. Project could be annoying at times. Most lectures were not directly relevant to project.

The in-class quizzes existed solely to check attendance, and definitely did not help with learning. Lectures essentially summarized the required reading, and there was very little actual programming instruction provided or required for the main assignment—which seemed unusual for a project class. Grading frequently did not have explanations given for seemingly arbitrary number scores.
You learn how to build a website which isn't the most exciting application for HCI but it's a useful skill; Nell was a good lecturer.
Grading was too subjective; very difficult without prior experience with HTML, CSS, and JS (not taught in class but necessary for project)
Not a ton of work. The class is much easier if you have a coding background˺lready know javascript/html. overall pretty easy! No tests or midterms.
This was a really easy course and just has a bunch of busy work in it. Great if you are looking for an easy class
The concepts were fun to learn and implement. Scoring was a bit tough but there were chances of recovering the lost marks. Not tough but needs efforts and imagination.
Lots of interesting topics, and the early part of the course helps you learn to code

Sometimes, it felt like we were not sufficiently challenged to utilize what we had learned in class. The material was interesting; however, it felt like the connection between the material and the projects was not strong enough.
Your entire grade is based on a few assignments and a quarter-long group project. Lectures are pretty much useless, but they take attendance.

Do not take this class if you expect to learn a lot. That being said it is a fine, pretty low commitment and interesting class. Lectures can be repetitive and grading arbitrary, but overall not a bad class.

Could be awesome if you have a great group. You have almost total flexibility of your project so I really enjoyed that. Lectures were not the most interesting though, lots of overlap with DTC and is kind of surface level.

I thought the project was a great idea, but the fact that it wasn't completed made me feel like this was a missed opportunity. Though understanding the scope of the course and the time we had this was understandable.

Class is simultaneously easy and a pain. Lecture content is simple and easy to understand but the main part of this class is the group project which can be a hassle depending on your project/group. Assemble a good team and choose a simple project.
Very boring class.
design concept
I have learned a lot about website development

The ideas learned in this course are very similar to DTC except that it focuses more on computer interfaces. I liked the professor and I had a good group for the project (which I think really changes the class if you have a bad group)

I really did not like this course. I wanted to learn more of the grit of web development like serious HTML,CSS, JavaScript (and even more like Ajax, jQuery, PHP). We didn't learn about any of this stuff. Instead, we focused on design principles and methodologies. Overall, I found this course very useless. It's relatively easy for a CS class / Interface Distro, but other than than, don't expect to come away with much.
Take this class with Ian, I liked that we learned it in C# and the style was good.
Take this course with Ian! He is a great professor and has a passion for teaching.

Class was not well executed. Ian can be seen around campus writing the slides for that day's lectures minutes before each lecture.. Typos upon typos upon more mistakes in lecture. Slides were also very boring and the exams didn't reflect what you learned about data structures as much as it did Ian's favorite algorithms. Logistics of the class were even worse. Many people get straight 0's on assignments because of "compiling errors" which are not the students' fault. Then when asking Ian for a second opportunity to submit he says okay but he has to dock off half the potential points.

Great class. Take it with Ian and hopefully Ethan. They're both amazing. Be SUPER careful you follow the guidelines on homework or they will give you a zero! Homework can be easy or challenging but nothing impossible. Quizzes are fair, just read carefully and remember concepts above code! (though, do remember some code!). It's a great class you will most definitely enjoy :)

Only liked it bc of ian. Please be sure to stay on top of the assignments or you WILL go down a letter grade. Harder than it looks. Also, no communication in this class. I didn't even know you could resubmit assignments you got a 0 on until during finals week, and it wasn't even mentioned in class.
Ian #1. Homework assignments can take awhile, write a lot of tests for them. Extensions were life-saving.
The course is interesting, and Ian makes it fun. The exams and grading are very fair. The weekly assignments are hard, but fun to do.
yes
The homeworks in this class were a little annoying but the exams are super easy.
The cutoff for an A is a 94
Do not stop trying in this class! The first half will lull you into a sense of security then BAM! you're deep into priority queues and amortized analysis wondering what just happened.
Course was very manageable, really good lecture slides, should take it with Ian.

I absolutely loved this course, some of my favorite coding because it's really relevant and challenging enough, but not too overly frustrating. Probably the easiest of the 212, 213 214 core courseload for CS. Would highly recommend, especially with Horswill because his hair is fabulous and he's generally the best.
Ian's a good dude! He's probably the guy to take this with.

This class provides some of the key fundamentals to data structures and algorithm. The content of the class itself is actually not too challenging, and Prof. Horswill does a great job in helping you navigate through the material, and letting you know what material is actually important and relevant to you. I felt that the lecture slides were some of the best I've ever seen, so much so, that many students (I would say most students) elect not to attend lecture. That being said, I personally think he is quite good at lecturing and you should try to attend lectures whenever possible.

The exams are not too difficult. If you attend lectures and is diligent about keeping up with the material, you should have no problems completing the class. It is extremely important to understand the concepts LIFO (Last In First Out) and FIFO (First In Last Out). This will help you grasp the fundamentals of some of the data structures pretty quickly.

The assignments are also not too difficult, but you should be spending hours (8-11) per week on them regardless. Some assignments could take less time (4-8 hours) but I encourage you to spend a few hours understanding the assignment, going through the lecture slides to understand the material, then proceed in starting the assignment. Once you understand the material, the assignments are not too difficult, because a lot of the pseudocode for the data structures are included in the slides. You will learn to debug through these assignments and it is an extremely useful skill.
N˺

This class was very thorough and while it wasn't the easiest, I definitely learned a lot. Of course, some of the assignments took a while to complete but most of them were pretty straightforward and were a good representation of the material we learned in class (aside from 1). I would definitely recommend 214.
It was a bit of a challenge but also taught a lot.

Take it with Ian and Ethan. They are fantastic instructor and TA. Assignment have bigger portion than I expected and when you screwed up one or two, really need to work hard on exams. but overall, it's a very enjoyable class.

Ian is an excellent lecturer. He's charismatic, enthusiastic about the material, highly knowledgeable, and always wanting to answer questions. The lecture aspect of the course was fine. The homework assignments were sufficiently challenging enough but not too hard. The automated grading system seemed to cause a great amount of distress to many students including myself because a single misspelling or wrong access modifier might end up in an assignment getting a 0. They did however warn of this in all of the homework documents and encouraged all students to double check their assignments. The tests were quite fair and tested pure understanding of concepts rather than memorization.
I think this course is what you make of it. If you really try on the homeworks, you will understand all the concepts and learn a lot throughout the quarter.

The projects are super easy but its hard to think of all the edge cases to test for so its easy to lose points. Also lectures are fine but hard to be engaging given how slow the pace of the class is. I think this could be combined with 211 easily, at least for people with previous experience.
Really fun material and Ian and Ethan are both great

Good course, class can be a bit repetitive and and a lot of time is spent on concepts you wont be expected to know or going into detail far beyond what you'll be asked to implement in the homework or quizzes. Assignments are pretty short and easy compared to other EECS classes, and Ian's quizzes are good evaluations of understanding and easy to prep for. Good class.

DON'T UNDERESTIMATE THE ASSIGNMENTS! It's not like 211 or 111. 100% is not guaranteed. some averages were 50. Its a tough class. quizzes are reasonable but assignments are super hard. TAKE THIS WITH HORSWILL

The assignments in this class are graded way too harshly. I have gotten multiple low grades for small C# specific errors, miss-capitalizing method names and inconsequential stuff like that. We should spend time going over what people did wrong in the homework instead of useless discussion sections. Never have I aced a final and expect to get a C in the class.

Definitely take 214 with Ian. He teaches it in C#, which is very similar to C++. Most of the coding assignments use pseudocode that they give you in the lecture slides so it's not too difficult. The testing schedule kind of sucks though. There are midterms weeks 6 and 10, and then a final in the class, which just feels unnecessary.

Class is relatively easy at the beginning but picks up in the last 2-3 weeks. Assignments also really range, and visual studios is not fun to work with especially with a mac. Make sure you know how to turn your homeworks in because a lot of people struggle with that. Similar to 211 in time spent coding, just like all EECS classes in that if you don't have prior experience with the language (C#) this class won't be a breeze.

Fun class, and Ian's great. However, one big problem with this class (and the other intro CS classes) is that code is autograded, without being looked at by an instructor. As a result, the importance of writing readable and documented code, top-down design, etc. is completely lost. Since most of the assignments pretty much involve copying code from slides and filling in blanks, students don't really learn how to code in this class. However, the instructors do a good job of making the assignments interesting, and it is a good class overall. Ian and Ethan explain concepts well.

As usual, Ian is a great professor who can clearly articulate various topics. Assignments are done individually, but because the slides from lecture are posted online and contain pseudocode, they're easy to complete.
I think it's great I learned a ton! It's a lot of work in my opinion though.
Great class if you don't have a busy quarter. Workload was pretty overwhelming for me.

This class is hard. Assignments take forever and are harshly graded. I spent most of the time teaching myself the material for assignments and the quizzes. Assignments were weekly, which was so hard to keep up with the pace of the course.

This is an extremely important class for computer science majors and I believe that it was taught very well. I can't imagine taking the course with anyone other than Ian, and hes just a blast when he's lecturing. The class, in my opinion, is difficult conceptually and you really just need to work at it and make sure you understand everything since it all builds on each other.
Very fun
The class is great. Ian's lectures can feel a bit dry at time and slides are not always the most intuitive.
Don't forget to register for extensions. The late policy kind of sucks!

Very disorganized class this year for some reason. We spent hours debugging a game we never used for homeworks, the homeworks were usually graded slowly, and the test results were in spanish, but that didnt even matter because the test results were just the names of the test, not the inputs and outputs. Lectures were well done and informative, but you learn by doing and the hw side was awful.

This is the class you need for interviews. 213 is an absolute grind but 214 is actually pretty enjoyable and interesting. You should go to each lecture and do the assignments ahead of time. It will definitely help you learn. If you've done actual coding before this class is a breeze but it covers some really pertinent topics. Half of software development is dealing with data and how to represent it. This should really be the first CS class you take after 211.
Ian is a great dude and a pretty decent teacher. The slides get really clunky (one of the lectures has like 240 slides!) so they really only make sense if you go to lecture.

As someone with no previous coding experience, I found this course extremely challenging. There are a lot of people in the class who have coded before and make it seem easy, so the concepts aren't always explained fully and the homeworks were very difficult if you didn't have background knowledge. Taking this course made me realize I didn't want to continue to pursue EECS, would not recommend unless necessary for a major/minor
Fine course. Many things to learn, but not too difficult. Ian is a great teacher. Sometimes there's broken homework code, though.

Very interesting subject, Ian is great at teaching, Ethan is a great TA. My biggest complaint is how easy it is to make a tiny mistake on homework submission and have your grade drop to a zero because of it.

The HW's were much more difficult than in previous quarters, in previous 214 classes you had a partner and in this course it seemed like working together was slightly discouraged. I think the HW assignments themsevles were all very interesting, however, they did not tell you specifically what tests your code was going to be compared to, so you really just had to try your best and hope your code was up to their standards. I understand this is a smart way to make students think critically, but it was also very challenging considering how much lower our HW averages were in comparison to other quarters. The lectures were very dry but the two did their best to make it interesting. the exams and weekly quizzes were beyond fair.
This class is great. Ian and Ethan are great. I learned a lot in this class and it didn't take up very much of my time. Also some words of wisdom - don't be late to the last day of class.
The class is very manageable and if you enjoy this class you'll probably enjoy the major/minor.

I enjoyed this class. I think that the lectures and slides were adequate with helping to learn everything that Ian wanted to teach. Ethan was a great TA. The homeworks were challenging and took a long time, but I felt that they helped me learn the concepts. The quizzes were all very fair.
Ian's great, Ethan is a great TA. If you did well in 211 you'll do well and if you struggled in 211 you will probably struggle again.

The actual material in this class is extremely interesting and useful and I did learn a lot from this class. There were however constant issues and confusions with homeworks which led to unnecessary stress. It made it feel like the class was built for you to do poorly because of all the issues with homeworks. Issues with homeworks grades took forever to fix. Also we had two midterms with no class in-between which seemed unnecessary and like bad planning. OVERALL very interesting course just very poorly run.

This quarter (2018 spring), the workload of this course increased a LOT compared to previous sections. In the past, you only need to implement several functions in a well-written skeleton, and only need to write tests for those functions. However, for this quarter, we need to write up pretty much everything without any skeletons, and therefore need to write more tests for every thing we write.
For the three quizzes, they are not very difficult, and people generally do well.
The grading for the homework is super slow, which is a bit annoying.

Ian is an awesome professor. He teaches the concepts and implementations really well. Except that he talks rather slow in lectures, which makes me drowsy, but I suppose this is causing problem only for very few people like me who tend to fall asleep when professors speak slowly.
The course was great! A good introduction to data structures, complexity, sorting algorithms, etc. Very relevant for the future.

The homeworks could do with more clarity of instructions, as could the tests. Perhaps have peer mentors go through them to see if there are any issues in understanding the wording of questions and tasks. Still a good class, and helpful if you are able to pay attention in lectures. It might help to have lectures not be entirely taught off of slides though. Can be easy to get lost.
Great!

Ian does a great job of presenting material that isn't necessarily exciting in an interesting and engaging way. The labs weren't always super interesting, but I at least could feel like they were teaching me how something works and how to build it. Quizzes were generally fair.
Good comprehensive overview

I was expecting much more out of this class - I was really disappointed with the level of disorganization in it seeing as this class is fundamental to any CS curriculum, and I felt that it could be greatly improved by adding clarity to the slides and not focusing on creating code that passes every thinkable edge case.

Good class. Ian is good teacher. Ethan is a good TA. Both are really patient in explaining things. This class is taught in C#, which is nice. Not too much work outside of class. The one problem I had was that I wished we covered big O more and we were able to get better feedback on what tests we missed on the homework. I've heard this section may be harder than the 214 section taught in the fall.

This course was quite good. I was particularly happy with Ian Horswill's clear and interesting style of teaching, which could make even the most boring and tedious analysis of some algorithm's time complexity interesting and understandable. The labs were a great balance between educational and not extremely difficult.

The material covered in this class is not hard but it's a bit hard to get A since this class DOES NOT HAVE A CURVE! You have to get 94+ to get an A which is a bit hard if you bombed one or two assignments and any one of the three quizzes. Also, I heard from a friend who take this class with Ian last year that the homework assignments were much easier last year since in a lot of assignments they only need to write the methods... But in some of this year's homework (the graph one and the Dijkstra one), we have to build the data structure from scratch by ourselves... Overall this class is really useful and take it with Ian if you can.

I went into this course expecting to really enjoy it but the lectures were incredibly dry. The assignments were also impossible if you didn't go into office hours. Even if you went into office hours, though, the TAs would only help you so much and many times they led me to believe my code was right when it wasn't.
Pretty good course with Ian, pretty necessary for tech interviews
The grading system was very slow and very disorganized with many bugs. Often had to get regraded to get the proper grade.

Data structures is an essential class to take if pursuing a CS career, and Ian helps make that prerequisite (mostly) interesting. You've still got some boring stuff like Trees, Graphs, Queues, and Stacks which you ought to be familiar with before taking this class, but there's a whole lot of brand new stuff like Deques, Heaps, RB Trees etc that really pushes the boundaries of what was possible before knowing all of this stuff.
Overall, the assignments were helpful and you could work through the concepts logically.
The course was fun to go through and reveals a lot of applications of data structures in today's context.

This course is interesting (and maybe even fun?) f you put the time into the assignments and learn the logic behind every concept. That will also help you on the exams because they're less about memorization and more about the concepts and applications of them.
Data structure is very important in modern programming techniques

This was, far and away, the most disorganized class I've ever taken at Northwestern. I've heard of a few worse, but highlights of this class included very slow assignment grading-- even when future assignments depended on the success of past assignments!--, mistakes on exams, and missing necessary details from the homework assignments so that you have to comb Piazza every week to find out what you need to include and don't need to include in your code. Probably the most frustrating thing about this class for me, though, was that in review documents and at review sessions (ones not during lecture time), the peer mentors and TA would say "don't worry about X, it's not on the exam," and then X was on the exam. You can avoid this problem by just studying/memorizing the relevant slides for that exam, and not go to review sessions. Altogether though, I think the problems this class had came from possible miscommunication between instructors, and the TA did seem to become more lenient in grading homework assignments later in the quarter (probably to compensate for mistakes?). Also, the TA seemed kind of overworked; not totally sure what the dynamic was between instructors behind the scenes. -Overall, the content of the class was at least interesting, and you're stuck with 214 anyway if you're doing the EECS major/minor. The lecture slides are really good.

This class will not be curved, and homework is graded harshly, not sure how many students can get A in this class. Still, the topic of this course is really important in computer science. The communication between instructor and TA is not very effective. Consider taking this class with the other professor.

This course helps me create a better knowledge framework on data structure. The professor Ian and TAs are very kind, patient and helpful. The homework took some time, but it's really worth it after you finish the practice. Great teacher, great TA, great class!

Basic course but not as in depth as it needed to be for interviews, etc. Grading is sometimes off for homework assignments; I got a 0% multiple times and had to argue to get credit (Ended up getting a 90% and 100% on the assignments I originally got a 0 on). Ian is an amazing teacher though, definitely take it with him.
The course was interesting in all aspects and definitely met my expectations.
Although the assignments took considerable time, they were very interesting and challenging. In the end, I learned the course material very well mainly thanks to these assignments.
Homework assignments are the more fun for this class than for all the other introductory CS classes (211, 213, 212, 111). Course material covered is also pretty interesting.
Overall, pretty good course. Grading might be a bit frustrating with assignments, but you will learn quite a bit about data structure if you do them.

I thought this course was difficult for me personally because I am still improving as a novice programmer. Many of the assignments were very time consuming and difficult, but it made a better programmer because it forced me to cover all the cases I may overlook while writing the most efficient program possible.

This class is actually super easy. Considering data structures is the most important aspect in tech interviews, I would've preferred a much more difficult and in-depth course. I think any student looking to become a software engineer would actually prefer this class to be more difficult, so they don't have to self study as much later. If you're facing difficulties in this class, and you're not willing to put in the effort to succeed, drop computer science.
Was good review

Ian is a great instructor, as anyone in CS probably already knows, and Ethan is a great TA who is willing to help you out as long as you aren't a jerk. The material is covered very well, and C# will make you forget you ever learned C++. The homeworks are harder than you think, but not hard enough to actually be a problem. Overall, solid class.
I really value the knowledge I learned because they are really crucial for future study.

This is the best course in the CS intro sequence. The homework is, dare I say it, enjoyable to complete, and the material is interesting. MAKE SURE TO READ PIAZZA and follow ALL instructions for homeworks. Exams are easy. Take it with Ian.

The lecturing of this class was not great, it was boring to listen to and a lot of the time it just felt like he was reading off of the slides. In addition to that, the homeworks seem to be graded in a strange way which results in some having very low average grades. This definitely was not a great class.

First CS class I felt was relevant and enjoyable so far in the CS major req sequence. Ian is an engaging professor who makes class interesting, while also teaching you a lot. Also the dinosaur suit he wore to class yesterday was 10⼐. HW projects aren't terribly difficult. Ian's tests are chill as always.

This course is incredible if you take it with Ian. The amount you learn about data structures and algorithms and fascinating. It's definitely the best course I've taken at Northwestern so far. The slides are very helpful for the homework and it's important that you understand all of the code if you want a good grade so don't be afraid to ask for clarification if you need to. Plus, once you understand the code, you see the brilliance in how it works.
I enjoyed the course overall, I found it very helpful and straightforward.
Its a solid class. Assignments are hard. But exams are easy if you do the assignments
Great class. Good to know. not too hard. Ian and Ethan are both amazing.
One of my favorite classes from northwestern. Ian is an excellent lecturer and so is Ethan Robison.

The course material is the most interesting I've seen in an EECS class so far (as a Freshman). Lecture is very useful and will be relevant to the quizzes and homework assignments. Discussion sections are attendance based, but I would encourage you to go and actually complete the code. It will be useful for the quizzes and the homeworks.
Overall a great class, highly recommend taking in the spring with Ian.

Ian is a nice professor and answers questions, but lectures move too fast and not everything in his slides is covered on the tests so it's hard to say what we actually need to know and what we can disregard.

I enjoyed this class a lot, Ian was a great teacher and this course is very manageable as long as you go to all the classes, pay attention in the lectures, and do the homeworks in a decent amount of time. Discussion sessions were very worth going to as they made up a big chunk of your participation grade, and additionally are great if you're confused about something from lecture or if you need help with something before a test

Ian is a great guy, really nice and helpful, but his lectures were..... so boring. I couldn't follow a lot of what he was saying, and he talks really slow so I often tuned out when I should have been paying attention. Also I was very very annoyed by the style of grading in this class. Ethan the TA would run tests on our code and just put in the grades without even really looking at our code. At times, a huge portion of the class would get 0's, and he wouldn't even double-check that something was wrong on his end. We had to email him, often panicking, to get him to fix our grades. I wish instructors would at least pretend to care about the code we spend hours and hours writing before dumping a 0 in the gradebook. It's pretty insulting. A good part of the class was that the tests were fair, and there were a lot of office hours to get help. The homeworks were sometimes unreasonably difficult and time-consuming. Sometimes the code they provided had bugs.

Very interesting topic but classic Ian class, kind of boring lectures after a while. I think the material, given how cool it is, could definitely have been presented in a more exciting way. Overall, not too hard, but you need to memorize quite a bit of material for the exams.
Interesting course, really getting more into the meat of comp sci and how data is organized (thus data structures)
I don't get why we still use C#, it's dumb. But whatever. Btw, if you have a Mac, pay the $40 to get parallels, it's 100% worth it.

For me, this course was the easiest out of the 211-214 sequence. It was very fun and everything you need to know is in the slides. The quizzes are not too hard and they give you the answers as you're walking out of the room afterwards, which I liked a lot. Ian and Ethan were great! I recommend.
I learned a shit ton and it made me a better programmer. Yes, the class is hard, but that's required.
It was tough but taught me a lot.

Ian is a great lecturer and exams are pretty straight forward. Assignments for homework can sometimes take a long time, and don't get graded for a while (it mostly due to TA's though). Overall, very interesting class

I thought the assignments were appropriate, but sometimes could just get tricky with Visual Studio and all its little quirks. C# is a very logical language to use, so I appreciated that, and I liked how this class focused more on concepts than syntax so we could write pseudocode for tests and that was perfectly acceptable. It's good to have someone available to explain things you don't understand - so office hours˿riends are vital!
Very interesting course. Homework assignments were unnecessarily difficult though. Very long and almost near impossible without the help of a TA to guide you.
This class is extremely important because what you learn here is very relevant to technical interviews.
It was an interesting course. Homeworks are not too challenging but you really have to do a lot of testing.

It was a pretty good course. It could have been better, but considering that it was professor Hester's first quarter teaching it, it wasn't too bad. Also, TAs help you SOOOO much, so make sure you visit them! Exams are pretty fair, but labs can be pretty confusing.

Pretty low-key course. Lots of in-class times to do labs, which are pretty straightforward. Instructor seemed to change the course content week-by-week. The TA (Curtis Wang) taught the course, and the instructor was just there sometimes, but he didn't really seem like he was that engaged/knowledgeable about questions -- in fact, Curtis was really the professor for the course and Hester was more like the TA. We learned a few things about timing diagrams, address latching, but it was much more a "do stuff in lab" course. Seems odd that such a big part of the course grade was exams, when there wasn't that much lecture content.

This is a great class on how to use digital components in a microprocessor system. The only downside is that many parts of the class go really slowly and are boring if you have any amount of prior knowledge on the topics.
This course is the best in the EECS department for learning microcontrollers and microprocessors because you get to learn on your own and get a lot of lab time for cool projects.
There is a lot of work that needs to be done for this class but it gets easier after you finish the first section (circuits with Taflove).
Not a bad class, but the requirement that engineers take engineering classes outside their discipline is intolerable.

This course is separated into three distinct sections. For the first section with Taflove, going to office hours are very helpful the lectures were very relevant with the homework. For the second section with Mikhelson, he does a good job keeping an electronic copy of the materials in class and polls the class for understanding. For the last section with Grayson, he really tries to engage the class and tries to make sure everyone is able to understand the material. In addition, watch out for the labs particularly in the first section of the class. While ungraded, the labs try to cover an ambitious amount of material and might not always work.

Professor Taflove teaches the first part of the course and it is fairly difficult, but if you go to his office hours, he walks you through every homework problem. Professor Mikhelson is one of my favorite professors and gives more than enough resources to complete his section (lecture notes, lecture recordings). Professor Grayson taught the last section and was able to keep the course fairly interesting with only an introduction to his section in 2 weeks.
This course is divided into 3 sections so I will talk about what each professor taught in chronological order:

1. Allen Taflove: lovable guy. He is very passionate about the material and wants you to understand it. The test for his portion is notoriously difficult. Study hard for it and practice all the homework problems in order to destroy the curve. **Note: go to office hours every week for homework.**

2. Ilya Mikhelson: hands down best teacher I ever had at Northwestern so far. Everyone loves him. Great sense of humor and a really nice guy. He's great at involving the class in discussion, and he's excellent at explaining the material. If you struggle or miss class, he tapes every lecture as well as videos of him explaining concepts and puts them online. His material makes sense and directly matches what gets tested on the final.

3. Matt Grayson: this guy tries to be Mikhelson but is just kind of a jerk. He tries to engage the class but its more uncomfortable than welcoming (you'll see what I mean). His material is boring and some things on the final weren't even covered in class.
Overall: Taflove is cool, Ilya is FANTASTIC, Grayson sucks but still take the class because Grayson only teaches for 3 weeks.
Difficulty: Semi-Hard (first half is real hard, second half is easier)
This course is very hard for an "introductory" level class but will teach you a lot about electrical engineering. Go to office hours for the course as they are very helpful.
Don't take this class unless you really have to
This course tries to cover too much.

Lecture was extremely boring -- Ilya's section was pretty good but otherwise I felt like i didnt learn that much in class. In addition, there was barely any material to study from online, when trying to study for exams it was frustrating because you had no clue what to study.

AMAZING COURSE - If you're looking for a general engineering course to take - take this one! I have always been so bad at learning circuits, but it finally clicked after taking this course. The instructors are ALL amazing. Taflove went really slow and took you through every problem step by step so that you truly understood each problem. He took an extra 2+ hours every day for office hours to make sure you understood the homework. Mikhelson has always been known as a great professor for EA1 and he is just as good for this course. Grayson is hilarious and takes the time to get to know the students in the course and makes sure we truly understand the content he's teaching. All tests are open notes, and non-cumulative, so it feels like we took 3 mini courses, which made it much easier to learn and retain information. I thought I would hate this class (because I generally don't like EECS classes), but honestly I haven't learned as much in depth in a course at NU as I have during this one.

This class isn't really introductory, more like intermediate. You should NOT take this for an easy elective. Most of the people dropped it after the midterm because of little curving. Taflove's portion is straight up hell haha. Go to his office hours. His midterm is crazy hard even if you know everything from lectures - I feel like some of the problems you just couldn't solve without having seen them beforehand and it seems like some people cheated (the ones who got near perfect grades but what do I know). Ilya's section is great because he is - he posts everything online even recordings of the lectures which makes learning the material super easy (and yes lectures become pretty optional as long as you watch them online). Grayson is super knowledgeable on his portion of the course and has some pretty cool ways of describing semiconductors. Overall the teaching became better with each professor but was always pretty decent. Learned a TON and that is why this course probably shouldn't be called just an introductory course. The labs especially are super challenging and 3 hours long but everyone pretty much gets 100s automatically.
I only took this class because I had to. I did not enjoy it but it was well done.
Poorly organized course with irrelevant, tedious labs. The cutoff for passing is very low, but the cutoff for getting an A is very high. The only interesting portion of the course is taught by Ilya.

This class was a massive waste of time. The labs took too long, and most lectures did not stimulate my interest at all. Furthermore, as a class that fulfills a Basic Engineering requirement, I did not take away any engineering skills or knowledge.
One of the best intro engineering classes in McCormick.

Good course. If you go to class and do your homework, you should be fine. The labs actually take 3 hours, which is less than ideal, especially because they include a lot of busywork. Grading on exams seemed to be pretty harsh, but you should be okay if you are up-to-date with the class material.

Kumar is really the guy for this. However, his teaching degrades significantly starting with complex frequency stuff, so make sure to stay on top of things while you're nearing the end of the course. Midterms are decent. Final is ridiculously and unnecessarily difficult. Be careful. Also, Mike is an amazing TA. Know his value.
Alot of useful content, Prem is a good professor, the labs are relatively tedious but doable, and overall grading is fair. Take this class as a more in depth look at the circuits content in 202.
I feel like I learned, but the exams were pretty challenging.

The class was difficult and the homework and labs together were very time-consuming, although the material in class was taught as well as possible I believe, although the whole class is based off solving circuits by hand which is pretty irrelevant in practice considering todays technologies

Awesome course. DO take it with professor Kumar. He is great, and he has tremendous amount of knowledge in regarding electrical˼omputer engineering. Tests can be a bit tough, but I think they are pretty fair in terms of materials. It can be just a bit confusing from confronting weird looking circuits and some twists.

This course is too fast and difficult for 10 weeks. It's a core class and I was excited about the EE major but I think I'm about to change me major because the exams were much harder than the homeworks, which should not be the case. Needs to be taught better or tested fairer. Maybe cut down on the material at the end to make sure you teach the fundamentals well. Northwestern needs to consider how it teaches EE courses if it wants to sustain undergraduate interest.
difficult and detail driven work, but hey, it does teach you the basics. just pay attention and for GOD'S sakes check your answers SOMEHOW lol.

I would have learned much more if it weren't for the professor's trying to cram way too much material into the quarter; Professor Kumar is an expert in the field and knows the material very well. However, he didn't give each topic proper time for us to fully understand it. The exams are difficult, and he is very harsh with the grading. The class is also curved to a B- not a B. The second midterm, in specific, was very time intensive.

Take this course with Prof. Kumar, he is great. Very organized and experienced instructor who is passionate about the subject. The labs are rather painful and are in bad need of a refresh. Exams were very fair EXCEPT for the final, which was not at all consistent with the difficulty of the homework or the midterm. Kumar put some tricky twists that were completely unnecessary, and graded the midterms rather harshly (i.e. 3% off final grade for a simple flipped sign). Might be a good idea to take 222 before this, as the Laplace transform is essential to 1˳ of the material, yet is purposefully omitted from this course, making the content more tricky than necessary. EA4 is 100% a prerequisite for this, but wasn't listed as one on the course website.

This course is pretty easy going while helping develop writing skills. MUST DO READINGS TO DO WELL. The professor does a good job in helping communicate ideas. Very helpful during individual conferences. Overall, a good class.

Sara was very engaging, personable, and always prepared with material for each class section. She made the course interesting by varying the content but tying it all to common, overarching themes. The feedback she provides is very helpful, and she's always willing to answer questions or provide further reading if you reach out as she is very knowledgeable on the subject.
The reading assignments were fair and most of the time were somewhat entertaining. Class time was engaging when we discussed the reading.
It is a great class for improving your writing skills as well as reading skills.

I took this course for pretty much no reason at all. I signed up for a sociology class in the same time slot initially, ended up very disenchanted with that class and the instruction, so I dropped it and looked for something that fit in the same time slot, and found this class. So, to be frank, I wasn’t really expecting anything out of it. However, it ended up being a surprisingly good course for me. I’d consider myself a reasonably strong/good writer, generally speaking, but even so this course taught me multiple ways that I could refine and improve my writing, in a variety of contexts. It focuses on multiple styles of writing (research�mia, criticism/review, opinion, etc.) and the instructor is sure to offer you personalized critique and advice for your writing in each style.

Overall, I was very pleased with the course. The readings aren’t too hard, and yes there are three papers, but they’re very well laid out with clear deadlines and goals, so they’re not all that hard. My vote would be if you’re looking to improve your writing, regardless of context, give this class a try.

I thought this class was helpful if you want to improve your essay writing skills, organization techniques and strategies. I found it hard to catch up with all the reading but when I did, they were very helpful.
Great class, learned a lot to help improve my writing, just go to class and do most of the readings (skimming them is fine)

This course is a lot of reading but the plays Dr. Phillips picks are enjoyable. Two papers, a midterm and a final. The exams are very fair and she offers extra credit. She expects a lot out of the essays but definitely pushes you to improve your writing.
The TAs and Professor Philips were amazing. AMAZING.

As a senior who never had an interest in Shakespeare, this was the best course I've taken in college. The professor is amazing and builds a personal relationship with every student and brings out all the intricacies of Shakespeare's plays.

This is an amazing course and Professor Phillips is the BEST! We cover a ton of material (it is definitely a lot of reading) but it was super worth it because of how much I learned. Also a good blend of text, films, and productions so you get a really well-rounded exposure to Shakespeare. Lectures were always incredibly engaging and made me think about the plays differently. Professor Phillips really cares about her students, too, which made the experience really enjoyable. Overall a great class, would highly recommend!

I really enjoyed taking this course and reading the course texts. I would basically recommend this class to anyone. On top of all of that the instruction from both the professor and the TAs was really good.
Great for learning how to read a little deeper into Shakespeare, not super difficult, good for distro

A great course to take with a brilliant professor. Prof. Phillips is incredibly adept instructor and is amazingly energetic, bringing up various elements of plays while also using other materials such as movies and contemporary references to guide the course along.

The class is a fair amount of work, as you have 2 papers, a mid-term exam, and final exam, as well as in-class performances and you have to be regular with the reading. The extra-credit work for the pop-culture challenge also adds a time- commitment element to the class, so it adds up.
GREAT COURSE! I love shakespeare, and prof Phillips is a fantastic lecturer. She presents the material in an intteresting, engaging way, and the papers/midterm aren't very tough.

This course was AMAZING. Prof. Phillips was amazing and I can't imagine taking this course without her. Her lectures were always interesting but it was important that you did the reading. Honestly this class is a lot of work and if you don't enjoy the subject or the teaching style of Prof. Phillips, then this class isn't for you. But if you do take it, know that she's amazing and the TAs are there to help you out! There are 2 papers, a midterm and a final.

I had very little interest in taking this course, and ended up taking it because of a scheduling conflict. That said, I am so glad that I ended up in this class because I have learned so much and had a lot of fun. Professor Phillips is a master of making a 100+ person lecture feel like a discussion, and the TAs are brilliant. As someone who only read Shakespeare in high school, I wasn't very enthusiastic about reading Shakespeare, but Professor Phillips changed my whole outlook on the matter. This is a great class for English majors, theatre majors, or anyone who wants to become a better close reader.

DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR AN EASY DISTRO. I took this class having flown through AP and honors English classes in high school with a strong Shakespeare background. This class is by no means an easy A whatsoever or even remotely close. This class is dominated by theatre and journalism majors who really have a burning passion for Shakespeare and the professor and TA pick favorites very quickly. The TA constantly had nonsensical comments on papers (i.e. this paper is too thesis driven) then assigned subpar grades with little explanation. Papers are also fairly long (4-6 pages, 2 total). Pop quizzes are given to ensure attendance but often include extremely difficult and ambiguous questions. Exams include identifying fairly ambiguous quotes and explaining their relevance. If you explain a theme different than the theme intended, you are penalized severely. Professor Phillips is extremely passionate about the subject, but my TA was pretentious and would offer little to no help in office hours. This was the worst and most difficult class I took this quarter, and I also took intensive abstract linear algebra. TERRIBLE CLASS DO NOT TAKE.

This was a great course for developing critical thinking and analyzing text. I learned a lot and Professor Phillips was great. However it was a lot of reading, about a play a week so it will take a lot of time, especially if you want to read the plays closely.

This course is good for people who are very interested in English, however I would not recommend it as a distro because there is a lot of reading and it was at times difficult to keep up with. It was extremely helpful to learn about close reading and analyzing text, especially considering our essays were normally focused on a very small part of a particular play.

I enjoyed the plays we read, the movies we watched, and Professor Phillip's analysis on the plays. The discussions we had in lecture were interesting, but sometimes relied too much on student participation when I wish I got to hear more from Professor Phillips.

This course was a pretty good one. It was interesting and Professor Phillips is very engaging and exciting. It was just A LOT to handle, as we had to read 7 of Shakespeare's plays over the whole quarter--which is a lot, especially in the tiny-font Norton book. The plays were fun to read, though, and it was interesting to hear others' perspectives. I just think it might be better if we could read even one less play, to have more time to understand it and go a lot more in-depth.

This was a truly unbelievable class. Professor Phillips is one of the most amazing lecturers I have ever had, and I could not recommend this class more highly. However, this is certainly not an easy and light work 200 level English class, so be prepared to work hard! If you like Shakespeare at all, you will LOVE this class.

Professor Phillips is an absolutely incredible professor and this class was phenomenal. Very few professors make the effort to get to know their students like she does, and the class, despite being tremendously quickly paced, was an absolutely amazing time and helped me learn a ton about Shakespeare and his works. I feel like I know significantly more coming out of this class than I did going in, and I'm very tremendously happy that I took it and would recommend it to any student who is even remotely interested in Shakespeare. Again, this class moves tremendously quickly, and I would not take it with an already busy schedule, but I took it as a distribution requirement and it was by far my favorite course of the quarter.

This class was a lot of work (obviously because we basically read a play a week) but in ways that I wasn't expecting too. There's a graded scene performance and the midterm˿inal are ridiculous in the amount of writing they expect you to do in an hour and a half (and then they're graded harshly with no explanation as to what you did wrong). It's all way too much for a 200-level distro, and even though I liked the professor and my TA, it wasn't worth it. Don't take it unless you're a theater major who writes well and talks all the time; these people were like half the class and completely dominated lecture and discussion, so I assume they're doing well in the class.
It was really fun. We got to act out scenes from different plays, and form arguments from the text. It was a great intellectually stimulating class.
Very engaging and interesting way of teaching Shakespeare

This class was great but not easy. It is certainly not an easy A, there are 2 essays, a midterm, and a final, and each of them are graded very harshly - maybe too harshly for an introductory course. That being said, Professor Phillips is a great teacher and really makes Shakespeare very interesting to discuss. She is adept at teaching a large group of student yet making it feel like a smaller discussion-based class. Nina was a great TA and super helpful - I would take this class if you are at all interested in Shakespeare or english classes.

This is a fantastic course. Professor Phillips is an incredibly engaging, incisive, funny lecturer who gets right to the heart of each of the plays. She has very high standards and I felt pushed to put out my best work all quarter, but the classroom had a very inspiring, non-oppressive feel to it. I felt like I really grew as a reader of Shakespeare and an analytical writer this quarter. Also, I had already read four of the seven plays in high school, but Phillips examines them much more rigorously than my high school teachers ever did, so I was by no means bored. I highly, highly recommend!
It was a lot of work, but forcing yourself to read all the plays and deeply analyze what is being said is a very important skill and I definitely improved in that regard.

Heavy reading. Read one play a week, for the most part. Two papers and a midterm and final. There were about three pop quizzes in lecture. Overall, highly recommend the course. Was my most interesting and engaging course of the quarter. Dont think there could be a professor more thoughtful, detailed, and caring than Professor Phillips that could teach this course. Definitely not an easy course, but completely worth the time and effort.

I would recommend this course to anyone. Professor Phillips in such an intelligent, informed professor who makes lectures incredibly engaging. Because we read and discussed so much Shakespeare in the quarter, I quickly became so much more comfortable with the material so each consecutive play became easier to understand and analyze. This class is a lot of reading, however. We had to read a full Shakepeare play almost every week so even though I absolutely loved the class, you have to be prepared for that much Shakespeare reading every week.

This course was excellent! Professor Phillips is a passionate and inspired teacher, and there was always something new and exciting to talk about in lecture. The TAs were fantastic, and I really got a lot out of discussion sections.

As someone who loathes Shakespeare, I found myself pleasantly surprised at this course. I was dreading it, especially after getting a C in high school Shakespeare, but this course totally changed how I look at Shakespeare. Readings can be tedious and the midterm˾xam is difficult, but you can easily prepare for it by taking good notes during lecture and re-reading the plays before exams.

Iɽ say it's a good freshman "intro to college class," but I didn't find it very valuable as an upperclassman. The exams are about regurgitating the themes that the professor presents in class rather than presenting your own analyses, and there is a lot of memorization required that I do not find valuable. Was excited to take this course because I love Shakespeare, but I was left disillusioned.

The reading is manageable but the course content is very difficult and the workload is high. The pop quizzes aren't too bad, but the essays are fairly involved (6ish pages of close analysis), and there is a section performance that is a very very difficult assignment if you're not used to memorizing and performing plays (I had to memorize about 50 lines). The midterm exam is difficult but manageable if you just read the plays, and they can't be easily bypassed by reading summaries. In addition to the pop quizzes, midterm, and first essay, there is both a final essay and a final exam, which really feels like way too much work for a distro. A lot of students in the class were theater kids and really seemed to enjoy it, but it's not that way if you have very little interest in Shakespeare. I had trouble keeping up with the lectures, but that's really mostly because I was uninterested in the subject. But I think Suzy is a good lecturer, and she has enthusiasm for the subject, so I can see why students who like the subject would enjoy the lectures. To recap, this class has three pop quizzes, two essays, two exams, and a performance. None of these assignments is easy. I would not recommend this class unless you have a strong interest in theater or Shakespeare, and I would not recommend it to people in STEM who are doing this for the distro. There are much easier distros out there. One final thing: the class is very geared toward freshmen, and the vast majority of students are freshmen.

This course is extremely well taught. Both the professor and the TAs are unbelievably passionate and knowledgeable. Every class is a combination of lecture, discussion, close reading, performances, film viewings, trivia and more, which always keeps it exciting. Expectations are high, but the material and its presentation are exemplary.
Definitely more time consuming than some other English classes. Professor Phillips is a great professor though and if you keep up with the reading (unlike me) you'll be fine
I absolutely loved this class, it was a lot of work, but none of it was busywork, Phillips and the TAs really want to make sure you learn as much as you can and are very passionate about the topics.
Kinda annoying course, although professor genuinely cares.

Professor Phillips is incredibly knowledgeable and so engaging. She is possibly one of the best professors I've had here so far. Shakespeare really scared me at the beginning of this quarter and her class made the material feel so much more accessible and exciting to discuss. She truly teaches the class in a way that shows how much she cares about students learning and your grade will truly affect the work you've put in. It's by no means easy, but if you show up to lecture and read the plays, you will gain so much from this course and feel challenged as well as supported!!
Professor Phillips is the nicest human being. Taking a class with her is a must.

We covered plays in different mediums, through live performance, reading, and media, which I think is important for grasping how the Bard's work can be interpreted. Overall the course is great, covering so much in so short a time that it's impossible to feel like you haven't learned anything.
The course was interesting, but the requirements of watching a movie and reading a play every week take more time than expected.

This course is really interesting, but requires a lot of out of class time because of all the reading. You read one play per week, and because of the nature of the exams, you really have to read the real plays.
Not an intro course. Extensive reading every single week and pop quizzes. TA also was extremely unhelpful. Exams were a poor measure of what we learned

This is a really worthwhile class. Phillips has a passion for Shakespeare, and it comes through in her fascinating and thought-provoking lectures. Grading isn't incredibly easy, but Phillips and her TAs clearly want students to succeed. The course isn't a huge time investment, and it's fairly easy to do well if one reads the plays by the time one is supposed to. Definitely a great class to take for prospective majors or otherwise.
It was an interesting class to fill a distro without being burdensome

Professor Phillips is one of the most brilliant teachers I have ever encountered. The way she engages with her students on not only an intellectual but a personal level is incredible. She knew every one of the 100ish students' names by the end of the first week. She took the passion I already harbored for Shakespeare and his works and amplified it by introducing whole new ways of thinking about texts I may already have read. I cannot stress enough that everyone even remotely interested in Shakespeare should undoubtedly and immediately try to fit it into their schedule next fall. One of a kind.

The class was fine. Although, if I could go back, I would not take it. I did not like the lecturing style of Prof. Phillips. It constantly felt as if we were in a high school lecture. It was a huge lecture, yet most of class was spent as if it were a discussion. It became hard to follow, and tiresome.
Everything Susie Phillips says is enlightening.

I loved this class. I improved my argumentative writing and close reading skills. In addition, I got to learn a lot about Shakespeare's works in a very engaging setting! You get the grades you deserve in this class. You get out of this class what you put into it. Solid class overall.

I thought the course was overall interesting and enjoyable. You have to read a lot of plays, but the pacing of the course made it bearable, and there were opportunities to catch up. Overall the papers were interesting and the tests fair.

It is jam packed with theatre majors, so the curve is not that good. As a comms major, it was sometimes overwhelming because the theatre kids always try to be above and beyond during lecture, so be prepared for that. You only write 2 major papers, which is not bad at all as long as you do the readings. The mid terms and finals are hard in that you really have to close read each of the texts and actually watch the movies on your own time.

As a junior, it can be easy to feel jaded in big lectures, but this was honestly one of my favorite courses I have taken at NU. I really have a new appreciation for Shakespeare's plays, and Phillips is so so smart, caring and an overall awesome professor! Take this class!

This course pushed my analysis and required that I become a more focused writer. Much of the readings were readings of Shakespeare's Plays with little extraneous material, which made the outside reading requirement relatively low. Both Professor Phillips and my TA were extremely helpful and presented interesting interpretations of the plays.

I loved the plays and enjoyed listening to her analysis, but the exams and papers were incredibly difficult and we were not prepared for them. The midterms had no review material or study guides, yet had incredibly specific rubrics and were largely based on memorization or details not emphasized in class.

Professor Philips is SO FANTASTIC! This was by far the best class I took this quarter, and probably one of the best I'll ever take. Her lectures encouraged me to think about the plays and to participate in class (she remembered everyone's names after week 2), and hugely added to my reading and interpretation of the plays. When you learn Shakespeare, you learn about all of literature, and as the weeks went by, I really came to a much deeper understanding of the themes and writing of his plays. Professor Phillips is incredibly charismatic, and manages to inspire students by making the themes of 400 year old plays freshly original and relevant to our time. This is definitely a hard class, with tons of reading and writing (especially in exams), but I was very motivated by the lectures to improve over the course. Don't take this if you're swamped with all of your other classes (do it right) of if you're not interested in Shakespeare and the process of reading and analyzing it, but this is an absolutely amazing lecture and is very rewarding. SO GOOD!

At the beginning of the course, I was definitely bogged down by the reading. I was trying to understand every little thing about every play, which slowed me down significantly. But, once I got a feel for what the professor was looking for, I began to enjoy the course a lot more. Professor Phillips's theses in class caught me as very surprising and were fun to follow along or argue against. And although I felt a bit too nervous to speak up in lecture, discussion sections eased that tension quite a bit. My least favorite part was probably the movies; I fell asleep most of the time and my interest in Shakespeare waned because of them.
This class helped develop my love and passion for reading, writing about, and above all, studying Shakespeare.

This course was incredibly well-constructed and informative. Professor Phillips challenged us intellectually, while making sure that her lessons were clear and understandable. It is a large class, but she made the class environment feel small/intimate as she constantly was encouraging students to participate/speak up and contribute to her lectures. She also remembers everyone's names, which just goes to show her amazing attention to detail, and the genuine care she has for her students. She is incredibly fair regarding the difficulty of tests/homework, and grading. Incredibly fair.

I had a great time. Even though it was an early class it was fun to be in as Professor Phillips lectures were always engaging. She lead the class in examining the text in new ways so that even if you had read them before, you saw a new perspective. I wish there were more graded opportunities because there were only two papers to demonstrate your growth. The reading seems like a lot at first but as the course continues you tend to get faster, and your reading more close just based on the example set by the lectures. The mid term and exam were both fair assessments of course knowledge.

The professor was fantastic! Her takes on Shakespeare and her ability to deliver it clearly and entertainingly in lecture made this class amazing. The TAs were also particularly good (a/o to Harris) and helped a lot.

This is the BEST class at Northwestern, Susan Phillips is a magical woman and truly changed/grew me as a learner and shakespeare-lover. This class completely cracked open Shakespeare and made it accessible to me, which I really appreciated especially as a theater major. The discussions and lectures were crazy compelling and interesting. By about the third class Susan Phillips knew every students name in the lecture... which was about 100 kids.
