I went to class every class (which is more than most can say as the 40 person class dropped to 17 after one class and by mid quarter literally 4-8 people showed up to each class because of how bad it was) and just counted the minutes until I could leave. The professor was never prepared and never seemed to have any idea what he was talking about. I was constantly bored and confused because he would somehow seem to talk about nothing for an hour and a half twice a week. I can not warn you enough DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. Whatever requirement is may fulfill for you I promise there is a better way to do it.

The discussions are in-depth, thought-provoking and interesting, but the readings are so heavy that they're simply unreasonable at some points. As much as I enjoyed the class, I would only recommend it to someone who isn't taking any other intensive, time-consuming courses this quarter.

– It was refreshing to have a lit class where you primarily read, without all the literary criticism and group presentations and canvas posts. It can be an intimidating atmosphere for a quiet student, but Prof. Herbert values each student's contribution and never makes anyone feel inadequate in their comments. He is extremely knowledgable and passionate about Dickens, and even though the works can be dense and there is a lot lot of reading, it's a good feeling to leave a NU course and feel that you have accomplished something. Many english classes these days are focused on more contemporary / non-canonical works, and while those are great too, it was good to read some major classics. Got so much more out of the novels than I would have alone, and they are incredible. Class presentations and paper is manageable. But reading is a lot; be warned.
This is an incredibly reading-intensive course. Be prepared to read a lot. But if you like reading, and Dickens, it is an absolute blast.

I was really excited to take this course because I love Dickens, but it was such a heavy workload that I felt like I didn't have time to actually absorb what I was reading and that I still need to read all the novels again to understand them. Honestly, not worth taking unless you are capable of reading VERY quickly and still understanding. Professor Herbert was nice and the course wasn't too hard, but it was a lot of undue stress.
Amazing course (one of the best English courses at NU) but LOTS OF READING BEWARE.
SO MUCH READING but good books.
Fascination, reading pleasure, deep emotions, great entrance into Dickensian world!!
The discussion in the course provides an all-rounded insight into three of Dickens's works.
The course was very reading-intensive, but definitely worth it. The discussion of the material was always interesting and engaging.
Take any class with Prof Hebert if you haven't!!!!!! The class is really reading-heavy, but 100% worth it!

Cannot recommend this course highly enough for anyone interested at all in literature. Professor Herbert is phenomenal at letting you just read the books and come to conclusions that you can share in an open and safe environment. The books, written 150 years ago, are made ever so relevant and pertinent by his style of teaching. Love this class.

This was a truly excellent class. Christopher Herbert is extremely passionate and knowledgeable on the subject of Charles Dickens and facilitated great discussions by always asking in depth and provocative questions. He is also very kind and encouraging. It is a lot of reading but totally worth it!
There is a lot of reading, but the books themselves are entertaining and insightful. As long as you put in work you will do fine.

I wouldn't want to study Dickens with anyone else! Professor Herbert's classes are incredibly engaging and insightful and I'm convinced everyone becomes a better student by taking them. I am always amazed by the conclusions that we seem to come to as a class under Professor Herbert's guidance - reading a book in his class is a completely different experience. I also loved reading some of the non-conventional Dickens novels.

Herbert knows a lot about Dickens. It's a lot of reading -- maybe 400 pages a week, and it's dense. The assignments outside of the hefty reading, though, are minimal, and class is discussion-based without real structure. I personally found this pretty frustrating, since I didn't feel like I was being taught.
Awesome class. Class is very interesting, and with a manageable workload. Great, diverse choice of reading material, and allows rewrites for essays, so your writing skills improve.

LOVED THIS CLASS!!! Bill Savage has the most unique style of reading novels I've experienced at NU and I had so much to learn in this class. Really great texts chosen and class discussions are incredibly dynamic. Savage is so flexible with how the class is tested in terms of paper due date scheduling, and I've never had a professor make his students' wishes such a high priority. This class is designed around the specific students in the class, could not recommend more.

Savage has clear expectations while still providing options for students. He approaches the text with great knowledge of its background and interaction with modern America. His class discussions are meaningful, and allow for students to contribute fully without getting off topic. There's a lot of reading to do, but all of the texts are good reads so it doesn't feel laborious.

I loved this course and found it very compelling. The books we read were fascinating and chronologically painted a very interesting development of American identity over time. I was challenged intellectually and in course conversations, and found the discussions we had in the class some of the most engaging discussions I've had in any Northwestern class.

This course kicked my butt. I'm a sophomore poli sci major and this is my first college english class. I was definitely way underqualified for this course, but it was also one of the most rewarding classes I've ever taken. I learned TONS about America, and myself, and how I think about the world. I LOVED, LOVED, LOVED, this class, but don't take it if you're looking for a relaxed english distro with a famous sex-advice columnist's brother.

Bill is an understandable, understanding, and engaging professor to be in class with. He makes discussions fun and the books we read were really thought-provoking. Never a time where I didn't enjoy this course.

I expected this to be a challenging course that would make my writing better. It did that and more. I really appreciated the opportunities to re-write papers because I felt that really helped me gain a better idea of how to improve future papers. I also think the response papers allowed me to read the novels more closely and pick up on things I never would have. Class discussions were always very interesting and I always looked forward to what Professor Savage had to say about the novels we read.
I think this class does not present many different opinions of America,

This course can be hard at times and necessitates a lot of reading, but the discussions in class are worth putting in the effort. Professor Savage delves into what being an American means, and how identity serves as a critical component of the American experiences. The class not only engaged me, but his edits on my essay really provided good criticism to improve my writing in the future.

Excellent course, especially for a non-English major like myself. One of the best courses I've taken at Northwestern, gives you a newfound appreciation of reading novels, and a better understanding of the American literary canon. You get to explore really interesting concepts of identity as well as various ways new ways to understand literature.

Prof. Savage is amazing and course texts were interesting. ~1 book/week, so there's significant work out of class. Savage gives a lot of options for course assignments to work with different types of students.

I LOVED THIS CLASS. This was my favorite course I've taken at Northwestern. I really enjoyed getting to read a wide variety of American novels, even if it was often one novel per week, which can be taxing. It's predominantly a discussion class, so you'll get a lot more out of it if you do the reading and talk. Bill Savage is a great professor and he includes some interesting lectures on what it means to be a part of a literary canon.

I would recommend this course to anyone at Northwestern, even people who aren't majoring in English. I learned more in this class than I think I learned in my entire junior year. Everything feels relevant and contemporary.

This course is challenging but Professor Savage is excellent. Don't take it if you're not willing to do a decent amount of reading. If you don't read the novels you won't get anything out of the class.
awesome course

As close to a "life-changing class" I've had at NU. Bill Savage is brilliant, and if you're game for some fast-moving, intricate discussions about identity/the texts, you'll love this class. It's challenging; Bill's a tough grader, but he takes pains to explain what makes a successful argument, paper, sentence, etc. It's a time commitment, too, roughly one novel a week (except a little breather around Weeks 5 and 6, which is nice) but it's one of the most rewarding experiences I've had at NU. Take this class!

I'm working on a creative writing minor, so I sort of had to take this class, but it ended up being one of the most interesting classes I've taken at Northwestern. I knew coming into this class that it would be a challenge — I've never taken a 300-level English class before — and felt that I was able to improve my critical reading and writing skills, which was my main goal. I felt the one drawback was that the class discussions moved too quickly. Often, the class was on its second or third ɽirect response' by the time I could think of something to say for the original statement. Other than that this class met or surpassed all of my expectations.

This is one of the best, if not the best, classes I've taken at Northwestern. It made me think in new ways about what it means to be American, and about how this country has evolved since its conception. The weekly reading responses made me stay up to date with the reading and hone my writing skills. The class discussions were some of the most interesting I've ever participated in -- I'm not sure whether that was a result of the students in the class or Professor Savage's teaching style or both. The classes were a mix of open discussion about the texts and Professor Savage lecturing about the historical context of what we had read. If you want to sharpen your reading and writing skills AND learn a ton about American history, take this class.
Again, I loved all the material Professor Savage used in this class, as he presented totally unique views on works that students are likely to have encountered before

This is a fantastic course. TAKE IT. There's an awesome reading list and Professor Savage is the best English teacher I've had at Northwestern. This course does require a significant amount of reading - about a novel a week - but it's so worth it. This class made me consider the American identity in ways that I never had before. Plus, there are lots of options for how you are evaluated in the class - Professor Savage allows you to choose how many essays you want to write for the class and then weights them accordingly. Great for all levels of writers because of that. The discussion was always engaging and very thought-provoking. Cannot stress this enough. This is a wonderful class and you should TAKE IT.
This course opened my eyes to a more global view of "coming of age" - great syllabus. I really enjoyed it.
Really enjoyed this class!! I genuinely enjoyed all of the novels we read, and discussion was productive. Prof. Johnson was great!

Professor Johnson was really interested in teaching intersectionality and while I really commend her for doing so, as a student of color it felt very basic and often the professor wasn't great at challenging students on their perceptions of topics like race and gender, which lead to certain students saying wild statements in class without the professor commenting at all. This wasn't helped by the fact that class is based entirely around student run discussion, which could range from really great and insightful to utterly quiet.
Pretty good course, the professor clearly cares and put a lot of effort into finding some great reading selections

This is my favorite English class I have taken at NU so far. Professor Johnson is amazing– she is very friendly and passionate, but also expects a lot from her students and is good at inspiring everyone to give their full attention and efforts to the class. I found the reading and assignments to be manageable, and Professor Johnson was great at teaching without preaching/lecturing– she let students lead the discussion while still guiding us and helping us see things from a new point of view. She also helped us unpack and think more critically about ideas like intersectionality, representation and diversity that people tend to throw around but don't always fully understand. The materials we read were incredibly interesting, and I found that Professor Johnson was a very fair grader for students that participated, did the reading and engaged with the concepts. This course tackles incredibly important issues and everyone should take it!

Professor Johnson is a really thoughtful and helpful professor, and it's clear she really cares about her students. The texts we read were great and the work was manageable, yet interesting. Recommend!

Excellent syllabus/materials. Usually survey-type courses (variety of materials˻ig range) are all over the place, but the themes of the course were clearly applied for each and every reading. I found this course extremely valuable and it's the best English class I've taken. Prof Johnson is great to meet with during office hours and genuinely wants you to improve your writing. Discussions are really relevant to current events and I think 10⼐ would recommend this class.
Typical NU english class. Prof Johnson is helpful and the books we read were interesting but everything discussed was pretty expected and I didn't feel like I learned anything groundbreaking.

There were some days of interesting discussion in this class, however on the whole I was not a huge fan of the subject matter. Didn't have to do a ton of the readings to be able to participate. I did not think the assignments reflected the tone or discourse of the class at all, especially because the instructions for each assignment were so rigid but the grading was easy.

This was such a good class!! The materials were really interesting and Professor Johnson was amazing! The work itself was not very challenging and the class discussions were interesting, definitely worth taking
This class covered such interesting stories. I enjoyed nearly all of the materials we read, and I definitely see this class impacting my future literary career at Northwestern and beyond.
Professor Johnson is wonderful! She is super helpful and kind. She really prioritizes supporting and engaging students. I recommend this class.
People really do not know what intersectionality is! A hard class to take with wealthy, straight, white people!!

The texts/materials in this course were very enjoyable, but I wasn't so sure they were all that interesting to talk about. The texts kind of speak for themselves, so class discussion seemed pretty relaxed and not super consequential, but it was nice that way. Professor Johnson does an amazing job at facilitating the class and is definitely a natural when it comes to being insightful, as well as letting students talk. Taking a class with her is worthwhile and I would do it again.

Stern is an amazing professor, but she expects a lot from students. If you don't realistically plan to read four Faulkner novels in one quarter, you're going to get left behind. But if you're jazzed about reading Faulkner, you'll get a ton out of this class.

This class is a ton of reading - 4 Faulkner books in less than ten weeks is not an easy task. It's important to do the readings, as almost every class is a discussion. Prof Stern is a great professor. She is brilliant and really encouraging

Every English major has said that you have to take this course before you graduate. I'm really glad I did. The course material is intellectually challenging (it is Faulkner) but extremely important. Definitely have to read all the material to enjoy or understand the discussion in class. This is not a class where you can expect to "get by" with skimming, because Prof. Stern wants everyone to talk and discuss (participation is 25%). There is only one 7-8 page final paper and two take-home exams in the course. The exams are close-reading so they're a bit tricky but are super manageable (i.e. take 1.5 hours) if you have taken really good notes all quarter.

The number of readings can be overwhelming at times but if you try to set personal goals for when to have each book finished, you'll be okay (maybe try books on tape as well). Faulkner's writing can be very disorienting so take your time. Professor Stern is an absolutely fabulous professor, she knows a lot about Faulkner and the academic theories surrounding literature but she's also very open to hearing new interpretations from the students.
This class is pretty tough but it's worth it; the novels are hard to get through but Professor Stern is incredible and the class discussions can be really interesting when people are engaged

I love Professor Stern so much. Please take classes with her if you are an English major and if you aren't one then please take a class with her. She is brilliant and kind and funny and perceptive and just great. Also if you're into great literature but are scared about it this is the class to take.

Faulkner is difficult and I didn't really have any idea what I was getting myself into. That said, I learned a lot and Prof. Stern is really really smart and cool. I would def recommend taking this class down the road in your English career, after you've taken quite a few classes and are really comfortable with discussion because I found this classroom particularly intimidating.
I would have loved less discussion and more lecture-style teaching. Everything Prof. Stern had to say was great, and I would have liked to hear more of it.
Lots of reading, but a really good class for English majors and minors. Prof. Stern is stern but great

This course will definitely challenge you in so many ways. Faulkner feels almost impossible at times. But you learn so much from being thrown into his crazy world! Professor Stern is so passionate and she’s great at helping you work through tough topics. A course that everyone will grow from!

I took this class because I love Julia Stern, not because I had any interest in Faulkner. Honestly, Faulkner didn't grow on me much, but Professor Stern is so witty and intelligent that it made up for it. Honestly Professor Stern is one of my favorite English professors at Northwestern: she gets everyone involved in discussion, made me feel like what I was saying in class was insightful instead of stupid, and even had an end-of-the-year party at her house during our last class. It's worth taking the class just for her. Our TA Brad was also wonderful, since he was good at rephrasing some of the loftier concepts that we learned into something a little more understandable. They worked very well together and made the class a lot of fun, even if the reading material wasn't my favorite.

Professor Stern's Faulkner class is an absolute Northwestern bucket list class!!!! Any English major (or person interested in reading fascinating and challenging novels) should do their very best to find time to take this class. Professor Stern is a brilliant teacher, with strong opinions on everything she teaches but also an openness and enthusiasm that encourages every student to create their own theories and ideas about these dense and amazing novels. A thing I really love about this class is that it prioritizes careful close-reading over anything else - there is very little work throughout the quarter other than reading and re-reading the novels, which allows you time to actually finish and think about all of the books. Highest praise!

English.instructor: COMP_LIT_211-0_20: Topics in Genre,ENGLISH_211-0_01: Intro to Poetry
comments: I slept through this whole course I am so sorry
GREAT class! Intro to Poetry was better than I expected. Thanks to Professor Gottlieb and the amazing TAs for a wonderful experience.
Honestly really really liked this course, the prof and TAs were great.
This class is not easy if you have no previous knowledge of poetry. It is not an easy distro class.
Great class, Gottlieb is a good lecturer and really wanted everyone to learn and enjoy the class.
Class was challenging. Professor was great
This class was so much fun! It's informative and will teach you about the structural aspects of poetry. The workload is light but challenges your skills in interpreting poetry.
Not as easy as one might think!!!!!! Gottlieb is a phenomenal teacher though. The papers were graded pretty harshly..
A pretty easy and good distro class. Not too much work and interesting material

If you like reading poetry and have a genuine interest in it, this class is very engaging. Prof Gottlieb is super knowledgeable and passionate, and the TAs are wonderful. It is also relatively easy to do well if you go to discussion and keep up with the weekly assignments.
I liked learning about poem analysis but there was a lot of busy work and pointless information
I would only recommend taking this class if you like poetry, since if you don't it can get super dull
Great, chill class! Professor and TAs are very nice and helpful, papers are interesting, and the final exam is very straightforward.

Great class, taught me a lot of things about poetry without being unreasonaby challenging. Fairly straightforward, especially if you attend lectures. Professor is awesome and got us candy, and Jonas was an amazing TA and lots of fun to talk to outside of a class context.

Lots of readings, which get to be hard to stay on top of, but a very enjoyable class. I learned a ton of new things and it was not too much of a challenge as many people take it for a distro. This class is a really fun chance to learn about poetry. Don't wait to the last minute to write papers!! And keep a running list of vocab words and definitions!

I would recommend taking this course, although it was not what I envisioned going in, I still enjoyed it. 5% extra credit to your total grade for reciting a short poem and 5 easy ec points on the final. Good instruction and teacher certainly cares a lot an is enthusiastic. I reread some previous CTECS studying for the final and I don;t know what people are talking about. Really easy workload and if you care at all you should be able to get an A. Definitely take this class

A pretty manageable course. A perfect amount of both reading and writing. I wish we were able to write more poetry and spend less time reading it. The class is not an easy A. Prof. Gottlieb selects a perfect variety or poems and is a great introduction to poetry. She is an entertaining lecturer, knows a lot about poetry and enthusiastic about the topic.
The class was very repetitive. We did not cover all the poems we read during lecture or discussion which left blank spaces in the understanding of the poems and the course in general.
I loved the course! I loved Professor Gottliebaand my TA was super chill and very helpful.

THIS IS ONE OF MY FAVORITE CLASSES AT NORTHWESTERN! Simply amazing. Not too much work, and all the assignments are engaging and rewarding. For people who have some degree of appreciation for any type of art, and are open to enjoying poetry, this class provides an opportunity to find great meaning in an entire art form, while not having to bust their backs to get a good grade. Nearly perfect course.

I loved this class, if you listen to your TAs feedback on your paper you will do really well! I had a lot of fun analyzing poetry critically and it was a great distraction from the stress of STEM classes!
The readings are interesting if you really like poetry. Keeping up with them is a good idea, but don't stress if you miss a poem or two.

it is pointless, just an easy distro; barely learned anything, pretty easy to keep up with the minimal work. The TA's grade the papers harshly because they have a COMPLETELY different format for papers than regular writing courses so that kinda stinks, but still expecting an A
decent distro, my TA made this class possible to survive.

THis class was pretty solid. Professor Gottlieb is very enthusiastic about poetry which makes class fun. My only complaint is that I felt that a lot of times class was pretty unorganized and I would walk away from class without really knowing what I learned. Pretty solid class though if you need a fairly easy distro.
It's a good class, and fairly easy. Take it if you're interested in poetry and looking for a distro.
Prof Gottlieb is AWESOME and Jonas is a great TA. Take this class, you'll be able to understand poems if you put in some time and efforts!
If you're looking for a distro please take this class!!

This class has a reasonable workload. I personally found lectures to be kind of boring and I didn't feel that I learned a lot from it. However, I loved my discussion section and definitely got a deeper understanding of poetry from it

You would be hard-pressed to find a more passionate professor of English, or indeed any other subject, than Professor Gottlieb. As you might imagine of a large introductory class, students were relatively unresponsive during lectures, but Gottlieb powered through with unbridled enthusiasm and good humor. If you actually put in the effort to do the weekly reading/writing exercises, you'll enjoy the class. TA office hours were extremely helpful when it came to fleshing out arguments for the two papers, and they graded relatively easily. The final was also simple as long as you kept up with the weekly reading, which didn't take long.
Gottlieb is a great lecturer, I had never studied poetry before this class and frankly didn't like it all that much but I gained a ton of appreciation for it through this class. Great lit distro
It was a lot harder than I thought it would be.

Essays are a grind but going to class is fun and enjoyable. Lots of extra credit offered and as long as you take advantage of those opportunities you should get an A. Class is not necessary to attend. Discussion sections were pretty fun and enlightening.
This course was really fun and easy; I enjoyed reading the poems.
Pretty easy course, very interesting lecture, and fun class

I went into this class with a feeling of frustration towards poetry, but now I truly feel more appreciative of poetry. The professor really helped me understand the intricacy of poetry and how beautiful it can be.
Good class. Frustrating when you don't know how to analyze poems - it seems like something you're born with or not.

Professor Evans does a good job of selecting texts that are interesting and provide insight into British history. However, exams can be difficult, as they require a lot of work in a short amount of time and only cover passages that are not discussed in class. You have to really like literature (and analyzing it) to be successful in this class.
I knew going in that the content of this course would not be particularly interesting to me but the professor and TAs were great and made it enjoyable

I thought this class was very interesting because it taught me to think much deeper about texts that may seem pretty boring at first. I enjoyed the discussions during section. Professor Evans was a great teacher, but the lectures did not help at all with the exams, which made them seem arbitrary and unnecessary to attend. There was not a lot of homework except for the readings (which you can get away with not doing every week), and the papers assigned were pretty straightforward and easy.

The course focused mostly on readings but lectures were mostly on historical context so lectures were pretty unnecessary because historical knowledge was never needed for exams or essays. As long as you could understand the assigned readings you were fine.
It has good readings though they might take a while. The lectures are fun and the papers are short. BUT it has two EXAMS which is a real pain and it requires you to memorize stuff.

Professor Evans does a wonderful job at teaching such a broad topic such as British Literature. She has great concern for her students wellbeing, and wants everyone to do well. She does her best, and that's all I could've really asked for.

This class was interesting, but spanned a lot of time. Professor Evans was engaging and genuinely wanted to hear from students. You probably don't have to buy all the books unless you want them for reference and to read other content, the works we read are mostly in the public domain and Professor Evans generously sent out good sources every week.
The class is great at helping you improve your reading comprehension skills.
Great class, interesting lectures, good readings

A decent class, fairly light reading load but the midterms are manageable yet tricky. Not as fun as 210-2 but that may just be the material. Random note, she never lets out on time so don't schedule a class north campus right after you'll never make it on time
This class had a lot of potential, but was very overwhelming. Avoid taking this with Evans - she is terrible.
Fantastic class, fantastic teacher!
Not the worst. Kind of rough that there's both a paper and a midterm, then a paper and a final, especially when the final is a lot.

This course was fine, but I would not recommend it to others. Don't take it if you just need a distro. It felt like an unnecessary amount of work with no room for personal growth. Personally, the worst part of this course was that they said they wanted your genuine analysis of the texts, but there was clearly a 'right answer' they were expecting, which was however the texts were analyzed in lecture. The midterm˿inal are unnecessarily stressful and difficult to study for. That being said, the lectures were somewhat interesting and the professor seemed nice and is clearly passionate about the material (although it gets very dry at times).
Lecture was AMAZING. Readings were sometimes dull but professor Evans made them interesting. The wide array of themes discussed in the course makes it very comprehensive
unnecessarily difficult for a survey course
I enjoyed reading different literature from the beginning of canon.However, most of the first part of the class is boring religious crap.
As far as basic major requirements go, this course was pretty entertaining and gives a good overview of early British lit. I wish I had taken this earlier.
You learn as much as you put in, and it's very easy to put in nothing.
Pretty easy class - do the readings, show up to lecture, and the texts are broken down in an easy to understand way.
The lectures are pretty dull at times, but the course was pretty straight forward and easy if you kept up with the readings.

This class is pretty fun the texts are interesting after the medieval period. SO if you can get through that then it is pretty good. I honestly think this is better than 210-2 but thats just a personal opinion. I would say do not take it for a distro because there are more fun less intense English classes for that. There were only two papers two tests and weekly discussion questions. Professor Evans and TAs are great.
Decent class, there's a lot of reading, but exams themselves aren't that difficult.

This class was underwhelming. Most of the texts we read, especially in the latter half of the course, were engaging, but the lectures gave too little time and analysis to each text. Professor Evans was a good communicator of ideas, but a lot of the times, it was difficult to see the relevance of some of her lectures. We would focus on the cultural context for half of the class, and then went into surface-level literary analysis for a short period of time before moving on to the next text. Then, when it was time for us to write our essays, it felt like I could've written the exact same essays I wrote without attending the lectures. My TA, Clay, made this class much better than it would've been. He led our discussions very well, and made clear to us that he was there to help us and improve our writing. He was very flexible with meeting one-on-one, and I learned a lot about my writing from him.

Prof. Evans is an enthusiastic and clearly knowledgeable professor, but the way the course is taught is somewhat misguided. The lecture focuses too much on historical context and not enough on analysis of the text, making it easy not to read before class. Evans relies on a question-answer approach that simply isn't too effective in a larger lecture class.

This course was very enjoyable. We read a lot of very different texts, stating with middle english and transitioning to sonnets and lyrical poetry. It covered a lot of material, but didn't feel extremely rushed. Professor Evans was amazing!

This course was solid. The readings are not the most interesting but Prof. Evans is a good lecturer and is very willing to help in and out of class. She looks to add discussion to even a large lecture and genuinely cares about the class. She models the close reading she looks for in tests and essays.
It was okay
Not the worst English class but not the best. Lots of poetry. Make sure you do the readings throughout because then you'll probably be in good shape for the tests.

This course is fine! I procrastinated taking this for my English major requirement, and found it to be a little easy and/or boring at times, after having taken 300 level classes. It is sort of reminiscent of high school teaching with the pop quizzes and the powerpoints. but, it would be a good transition course to have taken freshman year, and my TA was very helpful in giving me tools for writing good standard papers.

If you are taking this course, it's likely because you have to. If you can take it with someone other than Prof Evans, I suggest that. She organizes the course and assignments with too many tricks here and there - they felt like pointless obstructions to learning the material. If you have to take it with her, try and focus on the texts you're reading. Most of them are pretty great, and focusing on the texts will get you through.
An extremely interesting class taught by an awesome professor. Professor Evans is a fabulous lecturer--great at keeping the class engaged and interested.

This is one of the easiest and yet best English classes I've ever taken. The readings were for the most part pretty interesting, the workload wasn't overwhelming, and the instructions as great. I really enjoyed it.
Kasey is an awesome lecturer! The quizzes are stupid easy if you do the reading—I recommend going to Librivox and finding audio-book versions of the texts. Highly recommended!

This is a great course if you're interested in British literature, and a fine course if you're not interested in British literature. The beginning is somewhat difficult, as the readings are in Middle English and no matter how easy the professor makes it seem, Middle English is near impossible to decipher. You're better off just looking up summaries of the text rather than trying to read it. The texts in the middle and end of the course are fantastic and definitely worth rereading on your own time.

For a class that is required to complete the literature major/minor, English 210-1 is not a bad course. It's fairly easy, the professor (Kasey Evans) is engaging and passionate about the material, and the lecture and discussion style means you can get a good grade while putting in a not too overwhelming amount of effort. However, I would not recommend taking this course if you're not required to do so. Most of these texts are boring, and as a survey of English lit, this class doesn't allow for a lot of personal engagement and critical thought. The English department has so much to offer, but this course feels restrictive in its scope.

Great course! Would take even if it weren't required for my major. Professor Evans maintains student focus throughout lecture. Do the weekly reading quizzes (they're for comprehension, not analysis), and the rest of the class will feel like a breeze. Just don't fall behind on the reading, and you'll do fine. Professor Evans chooses her texts thoughtfully so you're not having to read hundreds of pages for each class rather sonnets, poems, short stories, and specific sections of longer stories). Highly recommend!
Weekly canvas post, one term paper, a midterm and a final. Pop-up quizzes are very specific questions. Texts are mostly Pre 1830s.

Professor Evans is a phenomenal lecturer. She is a brilliant person and her lectures are very engaging and interesting. All of the material is pretty interesting. The readings are definitely manageable. Take this class!

It is a fascinating course, would recommend. As long as you do the reading diligently and pay attention in class, you will learn a lot, do well, and enjoy. Both Professor Evans and the TAs are very approachable and friendly.
The professor made literature from this period interesting to me, even though I wasn't sure how I felt about this course at the beginning.

Really enjoyed this class. I didn't really like the first few weeks (because they focus on medieval literature) but once you get past that a lot of the texts are really interesting. Workload is very manageable and Professor Evans is a great lecturer. She does a really nice job highlighting what's important about each text and explaining the nitty gritty, while also giving you a good idea of the big picture and how everything connects thematically.

The lectures could drag on as the professor paused to wait for students to respond with the "right" answer. That style of teaching works slightly better in a seminar environment, but in a large lecture the class would be better served by the professor simply telling the class the information required and leaving dissecting the work to section.
I enjoyed the emphasis placed on female writers and feminism in this course.

The class requires the purchase of 3 $60 textbooks, which is very financially straining. There are concise editions of the textbook that contain most of the readings, and missing readings can be found online, but the professor makes no mention of these alternatives. Discussion section was very helpful, and the TAs are a great resource for writing your final papers, or just getting general help. Lecture is interesting, but very busy - the professor does not post notes to Canvas so it's a frantic mess to write down everything she has to say. The quizzes are VERY specific, and require an in-depth reading of the text, despite the professor's claim that those who read will have no trouble. The grade is distributed among quizzes, participation in discussion, a midterm, a final paper, and a final (opting out is an option if you score over 90% on the quizzes).

Do the reading. This class is really interesting, but your only grades really are the midterm, final & final paper, and reading quizzes. My only regret was not doing as well on the reading quizzes, because if you average a 90%, you are exempt from the final exam. Not a lot of work, and the midterm is easy if you study.
There was a lot of reading that seemed unnecessary, but the readings were somewhat interesting
Prof. Evans is an amazing lecturer. This course blew my mind every period.

I was a little intimidated by this class from reading older CTECs, but you needn't worry! The reading is pretty light, maybe an hour a week at most. The reading quizzes aren't nitpicky at all, and if you get 90% or above, you don't have to take the final. Lectures are pretty interesting for the most part. As long as you pay attention in class, this class is easy.
Good class--super reasonable workload, and as long as you do the reading it's not too hard to get a high enough quiz average to get out of the final.
The time span in which the texts were chosen from helps form a more comprehensive reading experience
It's a good class. Readings are fun and the Professor is pretty chill. Lots of reading time and prep work are necessary, but overall it's a good distro class.
I learned a lot and gained newfound interest for literature, which, at the end of the day, is the ultimate goal of any class.
This course helped me to close read in ways I hadn't before, as we read poetry, short novels, and short stories. This forced me to step outside my comfort zone and grow as a reader.
Take this class, it's not too challenging and you learn a lot, grow as a reader and writer.

This course is fine! I procrastinated taking this for my English major requirement, and found it to be a little easy and/or boring at times, after having taken 300 level classes. It is sort of reminiscent of high school teaching with the pop quizzes and the powerpoints. but, it would be a good transition course to have taken freshman year, and my TA was very helpful in giving me tools for writing good standard papers.

If you are taking this course, it's likely because you have to. If you can take it with someone other than Prof Evans, I suggest that. She organizes the course and assignments with too many tricks here and there - they felt like pointless obstructions to learning the material. If you have to take it with her, try and focus on the texts you're reading. Most of them are pretty great, and focusing on the texts will get you through.
An extremely interesting class taught by an awesome professor. Professor Evans is a fabulous lecturer--great at keeping the class engaged and interested.

This is one of the easiest and yet best English classes I've ever taken. The readings were for the most part pretty interesting, the workload wasn't overwhelming, and the instructions as great. I really enjoyed it.
Kasey is an awesome lecturer! The quizzes are stupid easy if you do the reading—I recommend going to Librivox and finding audio-book versions of the texts. Highly recommended!

Professor Evans is a phenomenal lecturer. She is a brilliant person and her lectures are very engaging and interesting. All of the material is pretty interesting. The readings are definitely manageable. Take this class!

It is a fascinating course, would recommend. As long as you do the reading diligently and pay attention in class, you will learn a lot, do well, and enjoy. Both Professor Evans and the TAs are very approachable and friendly.
The professor made literature from this period interesting to me, even though I wasn't sure how I felt about this course at the beginning.

Workload is very manageable and Professor Evans is a great lecturer. Prof. Evans is an amazing lecturer. This course blew my mind every period.

I was a little intimidated by this class from reading older CTECs, but you needn't worry! The reading is pretty light, maybe an hour a week at most. The reading quizzes aren't nitpicky at all, and if you get 90% or above, you don't have to take the final. Lectures are pretty interesting for the most part. As long as you pay attention in class, this class is easy.
Good class--super reasonable workload, and as long as you do the reading it's not too hard to get a high enough quiz average to get out of the final.
The time span in which the texts were chosen from helps form a more comprehensive reading experience
It's a good class. Readings are fun and the Professor is pretty chill. Lots of reading time and prep work are necessary, but overall it's a good distro class.
I learned a lot and gained newfound interest for literature, which, at the end of the day, is the ultimate goal of any class.
This course helped me to close read in ways I hadn't before, as we read poetry, short novels, and short stories. This forced me to step outside my comfort zone and grow as a reader.
Take this class, it's not too challenging and you learn a lot, grow as a reader and writer.
great books, too simple of a class if you're looking for legitimate intellectual stimulation.

Professor Law gave interesting and intriguing lectures, and I looked forward to attending his lectures. He was very passionate about the novels that we read which made the lectures more fun and enjoyable.

It was a decent course! Very similar to AP English classes so if you excelled there, this class will be fine. There's a quite a bit of reading assigned but there's only one midterm, one paper, and one final (choose either a paper or sit-down final). Jules Law is a good professor and his lectures are usually pretty interesting, it was a good course esp if you're looking for an english distro.

The course was highly interesting, not too time-consuming, and Professor Law never went the full hour and 20 minutes (something I respect, as opposed to those professors who feel the need to draw out their class superfluously).

The class itself was very much what you make of it. As someone who went to lecture half of the time, I felt like I was able to follow along, but I obviously did not get the full experience and analytical interpretation that other people did who paid attention in lecture. It's very easy to follow along as Professor Law provides a lot of good critical analysis that you can understand if you read a quick summary on Sparknotes. The grading is very fair for the amount of work you put in. Overall, Iɽ say it's a good distro to take if you need one.

Prof. Law is a genius and had so many insightful things to say that I never would've considered had it not been for him and his ideas. He made me realize that every single thing can be analyzed which is overwhelming but exciting to learn. Nothing is too much of a reach for him. Reading isn't terrible at all, you just have to keep up with it. It sucks that you have to do a midterm exam and paper, but the choice is yours during the finals. Take this course!

Intro to Fiction with Law is pretty decent. Not only does he have great music taste, he really presents different types of theories and challenges you to do the same. For the midterm, you take a written exam and submit a paper and for the final, you get the choice of going for either one.
This class has a lot of reading but it's interesting and not overwhelming. 213 is well taught.

This class was too big for a literature course, as student interpretations and ideas were not offered or discussed. The books we had to read were chosen well and the concepts the professor introduced were thought-provoking and very interesting. The testing methods did not really reflect our knowledge of the course, but they were clear and the instructions were easy-to-follow.

Overall solid distro. Professor Law is funny and engaging though class can get boring sometimes. One midterm, one 5 page short paper, and then choice between final˵ page final paper. We read 4 books and it was cool to not have a problem set for once.
Professor Law is extremely intelligent and will really make you think! Easy A if you read the books.

Introduction to Fiction does involve heavy reading since there are four novels that must be read during the quarter. The novels are brilliant, the lectures cover the majority of what the reading assignment was assigned. The discussion sections helped me and other students talk about the novel more depth. Overall, this is a really good course to take for those who are interested in classic novels.

Jules is full of energy and is a great lecturer but when you're not as interested in the material, like me, then it's a little hard to stay focused for the whole lecture. The class wasn't too bad, we just read four books, took a midterm exam, wrote a midterm paper, and got to decide between a paper or an exam for the final. Iɽ recommend for a lit distro.

Pretty chill class -- lots of reading, but Jules is an incredible lecturer, so going to class is legitimately enjoyable. Easy midterm, and then two moderately challenging papers, but it's super helpful going to TA office hours.

I thought this course was pretty easy. You aren't really held accountable for the readings so you either do it or you don't. The lectures were interesting, and Professor Law is pretty engaging, but it will not help you be a better reader or a better analyzer of literary text.

This class is a great class to take if you're looking for something that won't be too challenging but will be interesting. The reading took up some time, but the books are generally short and don't require a lot of effort to understand them. The papers aren't bad either -- just make sure to know how to write a paper and go to office hours if you're confused at all. Overall a very enjoyable class and attendance at lecture was optional.
I was excited to read the books, but the class went so quickly that reading and understanding all four texts seemed impossible. The lecture's were hard to follow, but discussion was very helpful.

The lectures for this class were so fun and interesting. I actually wish I had a few of them recorded to listen to again. My discussion section started out pretty slow but was interesting and engaging by the end of the quarter. The only problem I had was falling behind on the reading. For the big lectures, it really seems like its not important to read because there's no evidence of whether you did or not, but when papers come around you realize it is.

Good course. Readings were interesting. Not difficult. Lectures were a little strange - Law often offered perspectives that were intriguing but ultimately didn't make sense or didn't seem that relevant.

This class is a great distribution requirement class to take. There's only a midterm, a paper, and for the final you can choose between a paper or an exam. It was very difficult to keep up with the readings while taking other classes, and honestly I did not read every book, but when you could read the books they were interesting and you still learn a lot just by coming to lecture. Jules Law has a great teaching style and made lectures interesting.
Typical Lit distro. Not necessarily an easy A but the books aren't bad.
Alright class. Good for distro.
I enjoyed the lectures and readings for this class, but it was a lot of reading every week. I was never caught up after week one, and it was really overwhelming.
Overall thought this course was fairly interesting and not a bad distro to take, but it is a lot of reading.
There is quite a bit of reading, but it's tolerable because it's fiction. I liked the books we read. Professor Law is a cool guy. Lectures and discussion sections are enjoyable.
This course provided riveting interpretations of amazing texts without overwhelming you with too much reading or writing.

I got by in this course without finishing any of the novels (or even starting one of them). I believe this course to be more than achievable if you have upper-level English experience under your belt.
The lectures did not make much sense to me. The professor often went on tangents and did not connect topics. The class is definitely not an easy A as had been expected. Would not recommend.

I didn't always keep up with the readings, which made the discussions more challenging -- they expect active participation. The readings were interesting, and I was able to consider them as reading for pleasure rather than for school work.
Great distribution requirement - a lot of reading but evaluations are straightforward and fair.
Overall this is a really easy class, I didn't read any of the books in this class and the exams and papers still weren't very hard at all. Lectures aren't necessary to attend.

I love the books in this course!! Especially Mrs. Dalloway; Virginia Woolf is my #1. Jules Law is a very nice, helpful guy, but I found lectures to be kind of a drag˻oring. He let us out early, but it still felt super long.

This is a decent course if you need a distro. Even though it's scheduled for an hour and twenty minutes twice a week, he always let us go after 50 minutes. If you play your cards right you don't have to read all the books and you can skip every lecture after the first midterm. Jules is passionate about his subject, and follows the "English Professor" stereotype pretty closely. There are no small assignments so if you fail one exam/ paper you're pretty much screwed, so you need to study the right material, but no more. The TA sections were actually fun but unnecessary. This class is just very average, and will probably be one I don't remember taking in a couple years.

If you enjoy reading at all this class will be very easy and enjoyable. Probably on the same difficulty level if not a bit easier than AP Lang/Lit. Focus on improving reading and writing skills so grading is not incredibly harsh.

It depends on what you like. The lectures were mostly just, as a lecture is, being talked at for about an hour. The ideas Professor Law introduced were interesting, and the outside sources used in lecture worked well with the course, but there was little stimulation in the lectures themselves. The discussion was my favorite part, as it gave me an opportunity to analyze the readings myself. It was quite a bit of reading before each class, but nothing too hard.

The course is graded on the midterm, an essay, and a final exam˾ssay (you get to choose). The midterm isn't that difficult, and you get to choose the topic of the first essay. The final exam is designed to be easier for students who aren't English majors, but if you decide to do the essay, you have to choose from a selection of prompts, and it's graded harder than the first essay.

GREAT CLASS. Novels were super, and even though I had read several before the course, Professor Law discussed them in ways that were completely new and fascinating. Not at all heavy workload, one midterm and a midterm paper, and the final (either written final or a final paper). Discussion sections really help expand on topics in class and TAs are helpful with paper writing. Love this class
You do not have to read the books to get an A in this class
A lot of reading. You can't fall behind.
I really enjoyed this class. It is a lot of reading but Jules Law is very good. Lectures can get a little boring. The TA is awesome
The best English class I took at northwestern
There;s a lo of reading involved but if you stay on top of it you're fine.
I liked that this course gave me a new perspective on classic novels, a few of which I had read before.

Lots and lots of reading in a very short amount of time, but the books are all classics-- we read Frankenstein, Dracula, Mrs. Dalloway, and Jane Eyre-- and very easy to read. Overall a really good distortion course if you enjoy reading classics or literary analysis.
This course is not too much work and it a great class. The books are pretty good and Professor Law is great at teaching them.

Jules Law is AMAZING. great enlish distro if you like reading British classics and professors who play bomb music at the beginning of class. We read Jane Eyre, Frankenstein, Mrs. Dalloway, and Dracula. 1 midterm, 1 paper, and you get to choose b/w a final and a paper for the end (most people choose paper). if you do the readings and put effort into the paper, you can get the A
Quite disappointing - the lectures were irrelevant and unnecessary to get a good grade.

The course is good. It's not challenging if you keep up with the readings. I did not go to lecture for an entire month and I'm finishing with a great grade. If you read, and go to discussion, you will be fine.

I really enjoyed lectures and discussion sections, however the amount of reading that we were expected to complete for each class was often overwhelming to the point where even when I wanted to stay caught up and read before each lecture, it wasn't possible to read over a 100 pages in-between each class, especially in-between a tuesday and a thursday. The books were really interesting though and Law was a great professor, so overall I am happy I took this class.

I took this class as a distro (I'm a science major) and it was alright. It was A LOT of reading. I had already read two of the novels covered this year and only reread relevant parts of them for this class. There was one paper this year, and a midterm, and the choice between a final and a final paper. I took the final, and it was fair and a reasonable length.
I enjoyed the readings. The discussions were engaging. The lectures were best when concerning Dracula.

This is a decent distro. A little heavy on reading, somewhere between 50-100 pages every 2-3 days. As long as you do the reading however, the course is not that difficult. Professor Law's lectures definitely help in writing the midterm paper and final paper.
Professor Locke was an awesome lecturer. He introduced very interesting interpretations of the novels we read, and taking this class has taught me how to see the novels from a different angle.
Not a bad english bistro, a lot of reading though but you can get by without doing all of it
n˺

I think it should this course should be a seminar. If youre going to talk about ways one COULD interpret a text, you might as well have a discussion about how people considered the text. But it wasn't, so I didn't like it.

Really enjoyable class, texts, and discussion sections. Professor Law is an engaging lecturer who definitely opened my eyes to parts of the books that I might not have noticed otherwise. The exams and papers are fair, and you have a choice between a final paper or taking a final exam, which was nice.

This was a great course, and Professor Law is the best! He is so passionate, and he had some really interesting and unique insights into the novels we read. Fairly minimal work (only a midterm, a paper, and a final), and lectures were so interesting and entertaining. Not usually an English person, but I loved this class!
A fun class to take as a lit distro! Professor Law has a lot of great insights on the novels and the books you read are pretty interesting!

This course was very boring. The lectures were very slow and too long. There is a lot of reading that can build up if you do not stay on task. Easy class that you can get an A on without even attending lectures.

This course is a good intro English course. Not too hard, but you do have to read and think about the text critically in order to do well. Discussion sections are really helpful so make sure you go to them.
It was a good course. Obviously a lot of reading. The essays aren't bad and lecture isn't required.

The reading load seems like a lot, but as long as you keep on track with the schedule it's fine. The lectures, however, aren't that necessary since most of the times it feels as if Professor Law goes off track.

This course is okay for a distro, but the books are not particularly great choices in my opinion and the instruction becomes fixated on aspects of the book I didn't find particularly relevant or interesting. the concepts are also not typical rhetorical devices so be ready for that
I thought this course was okay. Only two of the novels I really liked. Lectures focused on really random parts of the novels that I didn't find important and discussions were not very intriguing.

This class had a relatively low work load, even though at times it was a lot of reading. But overall, it was a good distro to take; if you meet with your TA a lot and keep up with the reading and work, it should be relatively easy.
I loved this class! Jules is a great lecturer and the books were amazing.

This a fine distribution course, and while there's a lot of reading it's not difficult and most of it is pretty interesting. The lectures are really boring and uninformative, as it's mostly the professor rambling on about his personal opinions and interpretations.

Great class. Prof Law is amazing and so engaging. Would recommend to anyone who likes to read and needs a distro. Do not be intimidated if you are a non-English major- the TAs and Prof Law make the class doable for everyone.
I loved the novels we read although it was sort of hard to keep up with the reading.
This course was really interesting and not too bad workload wise. Great reading selection and Professor Law is really awesome.

I loved the lectures and their central themes. It wasn't like I went to class and felt like I wasted my time reading. Each lecture connected to the reading due that day and made me think more deeply about the novel and its underlying themes.
Overall solid distro class, lots of reading (which you only have to do for the first half of the class since there is a final paper or final exam). Professor Law is a good lecturer.
Good class. The exams sometimes feel like they're designed to trick you though especially with quote matching similar texts.
Good class! Reading is kind of a lot, but books you should probably read anyways. TAs were so chill, and only 1-2 papers which were pretty straightforward.
A lot of reading. So much reading. Lecture can be very boring though if you don't keep up.
I was excited to analyze texts, but we did not do so, even in discussion.
This isn't a bad distro if you're willing to read the books and go to lecture.
Prof. Law's presentations are a bit dry. Discussion sections are what promotes conversation about the novel.
The class was good. Jules Law is an engaging professor although sometimes he can get boring and repeat himself. The notes you take give you everything you need for the paper but the exam was rough.
Fun class, pretty easy, Law is awesome

Easy class - you don't need to go to lecture to get a good grade (although discussion sections are mandatory and important). I found the readings interesting but the lectures drab. Learned more about the books in question but not really any particular skills.

This was a GREAT class. 10⼐ recommend. Prof. Law is a great lecturer and his lectures are interesting and provide a whole new way to view the novels. It was never dull or boring and he went 20 min short every day for lecture, so getting out early was a major plus. The midterm reflected information that he had talked about and reading the books wasn't necessary but it made the class a lot more interesting when you actually knew what he was talking about.
Jules Law was so interesting and really knew his material and was a very passionate lecturer. It was very interesting and the books we read were fantastic.

I actually really enjoyed this course. However, it IS a lot of reading per week, so be prepared to devote a chunk of your time to reading novels. Despite this, the novels are interesting, so it's not too bad dedicating a ton of time.
Started off strong : first two books were well explained and I learnt a lot from them. Second two were kind of rushed and there was no real incentive to read them or go to lecture.

This class has A LOT of reading. In order to prepare for exams, you need to read the books because the spark notes can only do so much in terms of getting you ready for the quote identification and the mini essays. You can get away with not reading the books for the midterm paper and the final paper - but you've got to be really good at skimming and finding quotes and coming up with an argument. Lectures are a waste of time

This course was one of my favorite classes I've taken at Northwestern. Professor Law is amazing and very insightful, and I loved going to his lectures because he would always highlight certain themes and passages in the text that I would not have focused on by myself. The assigned novels were all enjoyable to read, even though it can feel fast-paced because we usually had to read over 100 pages each week. I highly recommend this course to anyone who is interested in reading fiction, even if it's not for a distribution or major/minor requirement.

I thought this class was a really great intro literature class, and the level was set appropriately. Definitely take it if you're looking for an easy distro. 1 midterm paper 3-4 pgs, 1 midterm exam, and a final paper OR final exam. Books are normally pretty entertaining.
I recommend this class. You're evaluated on discussion sections, a midterm, and two essays. The lectures were not really necessary to do well on the papers, but they were very interesting.

Take a class with Professor Law, he's amazing!! such fun and engaging lectures, the readings are fascinating (albeit he could do a better job distributing the number of pages to read), and the midterm exam was very straightforward as were the papers. Highly recommend a class with Professor Law, and I very much enjoyed his course
okay class. fairly low workload but there is a lot of reading. not an easy A

The texts that we read were very interesting and the professor was really into explaining the texts to us, but It takes a lot of time to read. The number of pages you have to read nightly gets slightly excessive but it's also what one signs up for and should expect when taking the class. It's definitely a class that makes you have to think hard because the questions TA's ask you in discussion are challenging and makes you really have to analyze the text. Overall it's a class that isn't hard if you want to fulfill your literature requirement. I really enjoyed Professor Law's way of teaching.
Ok class, sometimes it's tough for him to connect some really good points with larger themes.

I really enjoyed the readings and instruction for this class. Overall it was a really good class, though I think a lot of my enjoyment of it stems from the fact that it's a topic I am passionate about anyway.

English.course_name: ENGLISH_214-0_01: Intro to Film and Its Lits
comments: One of the most rewarding experiences I've had at Northwestern, great if you put the time in

TAKE THIS CLASS. It's not the easiest english distro ever but it's definitely the most interesting. Davis is great and you learn so much from his lectures because he really does care about his students. The quizzes were really straightforward and you have a lot of freedom on the papers to choose a movie you want to write about
This course is fun and interesting!
This class is amazing! Professor Davis is great and you will learn so much from this class.
Nick Davis was a great lecturer, and the class was very easy. However, having an awful TA really ruined this class for me.
This class is amazing! I had just dropped a RTVF course and found exactly what I was looking for in this class. Professor Davis is the absolute best both as a lecturer and a person.

Do yourself a favor and take this class if you have any interest in film. One of the best I've taken at NU. Professor Davis is an eloquent, knowledgeable, kind-hearted professor who will open your eyes to the nuances of the cinematic art form. Truly amazing.

This course was great! Professor Davis is really passionate about films and the movies he picked to analyze were all really interesting and fun to take apart and analyze. The literature in the class was also interesting, some of it was really challenging to understand, but Professor Davis always explained it better in class. This course really pushed my literary analytical skills, my writing skills, and my understanding of film terminology. I will never watch movies the same again. Highly recommend this class!

Davis is a treasure. He is, unfortunately, an all too rare occurrence here as an undergrad. I deeply enjoyed this class. Davis cares about his students, and he cares about the material. Take this class.

This course is great if you enjoy movies. There are three quizzes that test your knowledge of the films, texts, and lecture content discussed, so make sure you keep up with everything. There are also two short assignments and two longer essays, including a discussion section. Overall, you have to put in work to do well in this class, but it's well worth it.

Great course! I've always enjoyed film but got the vocabulary to understand the formal elements in a way I did not before. Also a great way to challenge critical thinking with comparisons between literary text and films. Not too much work, and easy quizzes!
I loved this class, one of the best I've taken this year. I learned a lot about film. The lectures were super interesting and I looked forward to going to every single one.

–Hard ass class. Essays were impossible to write. Jesus christ I don't even know where to start. Professor Davis is a good man and passionate about teaching, but he can be very dull in class. I feel like he's immersed in his own world of literature than really lecturing to students.
A lot of work, only take it if you're really interested in film/reading.

Professor Davis is an excellent instructor and is very committed to the learning of his students. I gained a lot of skill in not just analyzing film, but also text. I am a senior, but had I taken a class like this sooner in my undergraduate career, I would have seriously considered getting an English minor. I also liked the emphasis on film that was produced within the last year.
Great class!! The lectures can be a bit boring but you learn so much!! Not easy though
The films we watched were great and Professor Davis is the absolute best.

prof. davis is amazing and really passionate about this class. the workload of the class was spread out nicely but still requires you to do the reading and watch the films to participate in discussion section. the lectures are really engaging and i learned a lot.
Cool and interesting because of the films we got to watch and because Nick Davis is awesome, but my TA was a harsh grader so this was not an easy A.
everything

take this class! nick davis knows SO MUCH and is a WONDERFUL professor. if you do the readings, watch the films, and attend lecture, you'll be right on track to get an A. the quizzes are great tools to show what you know and make sure that you're keeping up

It was a cool course with interesting subject matter that was fun to learn about. Professor Davis is great at talking about both film and literature and does a good job at making the lectures engaging.
Discussion sections with my TA allowed for a more intimate setting in which I felt most comfortable to discuss readings.

THIS IS BY FAR THE BEST CLASS I HAVE TAKEN AT NORTHWESTERN. Nick Davis is an incredibly intelligent and engaging lecturer and my TA was knowledgeable and helpful in providing a lot of productive feedback. The work load may seem like a lot but if you plan carefully it shouldn't be that bad. I am an extremely slow reader and for the most part most of the readings/movies that I had to read/watch went by super quickly because most assignments are very entertaining. 10000⼐ would take again!

This class is amazing! Professor Davis is not only one of the most personable, enthusiastic, genuinely sweet professors at Northwestern, but listening to him lecture about film is like having a conversation over coffee with someone who knows basically everything. He presents ways of thinking about film rather than things to think about certain films; encourages students to have intellectual dialogues not only with each other but in their own heads; and manages, somehow, to be simultaneously incredibly academic about what he is teaching and also so much fun to listen to.

This class is AMAZING!!EVERYONE SHOULD TAKE THIS CLASS!! Professor Davis is the best and really changes the way you approach watching movies and understand how some of the choices into making the movie change how you watch it. Also really interesting to see how movies adapts its text and the different choices that were used to reflect the same meaning in the text. It is a good amount of work; reading a book/short story and watching a movie for every week and gets more intense towards the end of the quarter. There are also only two papers and 2 smaller assignments throughout the quarter.
I learned a lot in this course and it greatly challenged my thoughts on film. The course was a lot of work and difficult, but resulted in much learning.

I looooooved this class! Professor Davis is an amazing lecturer and cares about his students and the materials. The TAs are great, and the assessments are good measurement of what you're learning. It takes time to do the readings and watch the movies, but they're all interesting and make for good conversations and papers. Take this class if you like movies or literature!
Really liked most of the movies and books we read. Loved hearing Professor Davis's thoughts and insights
I really enjoyed the days when we talked about the film and the book together. Those, to me, were the most rewarding and interesting.
It was a good class and I learned a lot

It's a fun class- go to lectures, Davis is a fun guy. It's a lot of work because you have to watch at least a movie and a couple of short books a week, and the grading can be somewhat strict. Take if you're a good writer and you like movies.

This will be the best class you ever take during your time at NU! Take it with Prof. Davis he's so passionate about the material and the students themselves that going to lecture is an eye opening experience every time you go. This was a 9:30 and I was pumped to go every time, don't expect an easy A though, you'll have to work for it but it's so worth it.
I am now aware of many film techniques that is very useful in daily lives.
This is a great distro, not easy but worth it! Davis is absolutely amazing and makes the class really meaningful.
Very good distro. Fun class with good reading, writing, and movie watching assignments. Professor Davis is great.

This is a really interesting class, but is definitely not easy. The readings really pile up quickly and it can become really easy to fall behind. If you have the time to commit to this class, you should take it because Davis is great, otherwise it will turn into a hassle.
Really great course, Davis is knowledgeable and an incredible lecturer.

This class was amazing. It is time consuming because you have to watch movies that are 2 to 3 hours long as well as different reading material like novels, short stories, plays, and essays. But if you commit to doing all of the homework the distro is rather easy and enjoyable. The movies included vary from black and white to recent Oscar winners. The professor makes the lecture enjoyable. I would recommend going to all the lectures becasue despite the slides being on the canvas website you will miss things if you dont go.
Professor Davis is great and provides tons of insight on the films in the class. Very good literature˿ine arts disto, limited reading.

Davis is one of the best professors I've ever had, both in how he lectures and how he interacts with students. He's super accessible, incredibly nice, super committed (he Skyped into class the day after a surgery so that he could give us important info himself), and SO KNOWLEDGABLE. Make sure you have enough time in your schedule to spend time with the movies and the texts in this class because they're awesome and it sucks when you have to miss content because you don't have time. But take this class.

NOT AN EASY A. WITH THAT SAID, YOU LEARN SO MUCH IN THIS CLASS. PROFESSOR DAVIS IS AN OUTSTANDING LECTURER AND HAS CLEARLY PUT MUCH TIME AND THOUGHT INTO THIS COURSE. HE ALSO LEARNS NAMES REALLY WELL WHICH IS REALLY IMPRESSIVE.

This course is phenomenal. I love films and writing and this course brought both of those elements together. I have never learned so much about the making and the details of and in a film before. Watching fantastic movies and reading their texts and discussing them is amazing and with a professor and TA's and students who are engaged into it as well is awesome. I HIGHLY RECOMMEND and encourage everyone to take this course because it was fun, challenging, and opens your eyes to the world of film in a new way I never saw before.

SUCH AN AWESOME COURSE!!!!!!! Take it take it take it. At first it may seem like a lot of work but it was very doable and most of the work is watching movies. Professor Davis is amazing, his lectures are exciting, he's funny and truly teaches you to analyze film even if this is the first film-related class you take. Maria is the best TA!!!!
This class was amazing. It helped me analyze film and its literature(s) at a spectacular level. Nick Davis is an awesome professor and he knows a lot about what he teaches.
The course covered an array of films, exposing me to styles and techniques I had not heard of before, even with films Iɽ already seen. I will not look at cinema the same way again.

i don't know, i thought this class was okay. i took it because a lot of my friends raved about it, but i think film just isn't really for me. i think if you know you're interested in film though, youɽ probably really enjoy it.
Great class!

Prof. Davis is amazing and the subject matter was really interesting. I got to see a lot of amazing movies and read the texts that they were adapted from. I really was able to look at film with a new eye by the end of the quarter.

Take this class! It is super interesting and you'll watch some great movies and texts you never would have been exposed to. Grading not too harsh. Prof is very nice with the quizzes, tells you when they're going to be and the questions weren't bad at all.

Proffesor Davis is amazing and this course is amazing. I am a stem guy and I still really resonated with this course. It somehow finds a way to engage deep social issues in the context of directorial work, and you really always will have something to talk about. Iɽ say the hardest part is actually watching the movies on time-- a three hour film can be surprisingly long the night before a 9am class-- but if you aren't the procrastinator type then this class should be all fun all quarter.

This is an ok course- professor newman knows her stuff and encourages participation in class through questions. she offers pretty static interpretations however and there is a lot of reading for every class so that can be overwhelming. Overall- i learned a lot and became very familiar with the bible, especially the old testament but the reading has a lot of characters and different stories and to do well you have to keep up with the reading.

This is definitely a great course! For a lit. and fine arts distro, it was actually extremely manageable. Easy A in my opinion as long as you do all of the work. Anad not to mention, the material is both incredibly interesting and prof newman makes it easy to follow along in class. Toally recommend taking this class!!

As someone who is not at all religious, I absolutely adored this course. I learned so much about the text of arguably the most important and influential book in western history and for that I'm grateful. Even more, this course was taught in a non-religious way, focusing more on the literary aspects of the Bible which I found fascinating, especially in our analysis of the Bible and potential future application of its key themes and ideas in creative writing. Anyone at all interested in reading/writing should take this course.

This class was great. Though the Bible can be a lot of reading, it was spaced quite well and lectures made the material worth reading. Prof. Newman is incredibly insightful. Also, the class is not too heavy in outside work, as there are weekly Canvas posts, one 5 page essay, and 4 quizzes in section over basic terms. Highly recommend.
