Pretty useful class. You learn a ton of applicable knowledge that I've been able to connect with my other classes this quarter. Colyvas is the best, definitely makes you feel like you have an ally at the front of the class.

Prof. Colyvas is one of my favorite professors I've ever had. She really wants everyone to learn, she is very fair and invested in her students. The class is not vey time consuming. You have to read one or two studies every week which are usually interesting and write a short memo on them. The final project is the only other assignment and Prof. Colyvas gives you tons of time in class to work on it and get her feedback. The class is very laid back - first half is usually discussion of the readings and learning concepts, the last hour is time to work on your project -- and you can leave early if you really want to. Great LOC course.
Relevant and interesting readings provide a lot of material to learn about organizational theory, research and the methodologies.
there are weekly memos and to get the highest grade on them just do exactly what the directions say. pretty easy class but the final project is extensive so get a good group

This was a really good LOC class, but definitely a commitment. Be prepared because you have to be at every class and it includes a group project that goes throughout the entire quarter. There is a fair amount of reading some weeks, but you learn a lot about reading journals and studies and you take a lot away from it.
class discussion was extremely helpful in understanding the complex readings each week

Awesome class! A bit more theoretically advanced than some other LOC classes, so Iɽ recommend taking it as an upperclassman. Professor Colyvas is wonderful. Make sure you get a good group for the project and work closely with professor and TA to execute the proposal!
Teacher talked a little too much

While the 6-9 PM time slot is pretty brutal, Professor Colyvas made it bearable. The final project took quite a bit of time, so make sure to get started on that early. Luckily, you also get some class time to work on the project.
Very interesting class with a great professor. Learned a lot.

Professor Colyvas is very engaging and this class definitely helps you to look at organizational issues form new perspectives. My only real complaint is that Professor Colyvas says she is flexible yet has no excused absences, even in the case of an emergency.

Very interesting course, the papers we read were dense but made more sense as the class went on, which was cool to experience. I did not pick up many "tools for organizational analysis," as the title says, but the course definitely helped me learn to think critically about academic research.
Loved this class and learned so much from it
Not that bad of a class. Readings are dense but not that bad to get through once you get a hang for the weekly assignment. Class is tough because 3 hours, but you'll survive.
Very reasonable course. This class will expand your thinking and Professor Colyvas is awesome.

Great course, have to do some in depth readings, and weekly 1-2 page memos about the readings. Its graded by check minus, check, check plus, so she doesn't really count it as a grade, its actually about getting better at analysis and writing.
Good course! prof Colyvas is fun to listen to and keeps things interesting- deff take!
Colyvas was a wonderful professor. She cares about the students, and she made the whole class experience a really good one. Gabby was an awesome TA, too.

I have mixed feelings about this class... I didn't really enjoy going to it, but Prof Colyvas is really passionate about the class so you feel bad if you don't work hard in it. Also the readings are very difficult and the weekly memos were graded kind of hard lowkey. Idk, iɽ take it bc there's no midterm, but the final project is super in depth and specific. Ask for her help a lot. she loves to help. For LOC majors take SESP 303 with Danny Cohen instead to fulfill the requirement.
Lots of information presented that is interesting and challenging. Each week covers new topics but by the end you understand the overarching method well.

Professor Colyvas is very knowledgeable, friendly, and a fantastic professor. This class can be slightly long at 3 hours every week, but there are lots of interesting theories to be learned about organizational functions. The readings can be boring, but as long as you understand the main point and takeaways you should be fine. Work-intensive class but not difficult.
Amazing class, professor Colyvas is friendly and extremely helpful. Will definitely be looking for more of her courses in the future.
Colyvas does an excellent job of communicating with students, and making an analysis of the readings very interesting.
Good syllabua

The weekly memos for this course could get tedious but the feedback was helpful so that you knew what to improve on each week. I really enjoyed the final project, which was a research proposal for a question that you were interested in and got to choose with your group. I learned a lot about research design but felt that it was because my group sought out help rather than it being taught to us. Groups that didn't seek as much help had research designs that were missing key components. Professor Colyvas is really knowledgeable and passionate about her subject matter. Even though class was during dinner hours, which is when my energy levels are low, I always looked forward to going to her course.
Very instructional
Overall this class was challenging at first because of the weekly memos. But after the first couple of weeks they get much easier and helped me better understand why organizational tools matter.

I thought I would like this class more. Professor Stevens is great but papers are graded very hard by the TA. It's very hard to stay awake during the three-hour block, especially at 9am on a Monday. I pull a lot of all-nighters on Sundays because of the way all my classes had things due on Monday and Tuesday every week, so this class became very hard to bear.
too much work, final paper is really long, weekly assignments, not really interesting unless you're interested in the subject. not really for me
I really enjoyed this class.
This was a really great applicable class. Highly recommend
Definitely one of my favorite courses at NU. It's such a relevant and effective course for the LOC major. I didn't take 214 but I'm glad I chose to take 213 instead.

I took this class just as a major requirement, but it turned out to be one of the best ones I've taken so far. Reed is a very engaging and knowledgeable professor, and even though the classes are 3 hours long they go by quite quickly. Good balance of individual papers and group work with very fair grading. The final project was a significant group time commitment, but being able to choose your own group and project topic definitely helped. Would definitely recommend!
FANTASTIC, truly a unique course among LOC courses
Interesting content and materials, lectures are okay, final project is manageable
Probably the best class I have taken so far at Northwestern. Class is very hands-on and the main project forces you to learn by doing and how to create meaningful change

This course was interesting and engaging but some of the assignments were unnecessarily long. Weekly reading snapshots kind of got old but you learn how to manage them. The group project and the end was the most beneficial for me. Make sure you get into a good group for the final project. The final paper was long, but it was interesting. The professor and TA were always available to help. Not a bad course. The 3 hour class made it somewhat boring at times though.

The class was fine. I feel as though there wasn't enough support on the final project and the instructors give really loose guidelines which make completing assignments tricky. Class is a long 3 hours. The professor is enthusiastic and knowledgable, but doesn't always use class time efficiently. He kind of drones on and we spend too much time discussing the reading.

Fantastic course. Prof. Stevens knows leaders in the field, is doing what he's teaching and makes the class applicable to many parts of life. A lot of work, but you'll get a lot out if you put a lot in.
There wasn't a whole lot of work and the work we did do wasn't very hard
It was a very interesting and manageable class. Weekly snapshots can take a while, but the readings are interesting. Fieldwork assignments are also fun!

Prof. Hudson made things fun and I thought he had a good approach to teaching theory. The class gets kinda boring as you just go through species after species of counterpoint with no breaks or detours in the curriculum but it's fine and the expectations are, for the most part, super reasonable.
This class is fantastic, I hear all the teachers were great and the evaluations are as clear cut as can be. They really encourage you to do well.
It's a required class, but Cline is a good professor and is engaging.
This course taught us what we needed to know and stayed engaging.
This course was overall a really great music theory class.
Not a lot of work outside of class, lots of workshopping and group work in class... Dr. P was really helpful
Nice hands on approach.
It is pretty cool, ultimately, that I was able to compose a basic canon with embellishments at the end. It found it pretty exciting.
I love this class and I have learned so much in it.

I never knew much about music theory before taking this course so it was really interesting to relate it back to playing my instrument. Dr. P. is a very genuine and awesome teacher. She really cares about her students a lot and is passionate about teaching. she makes what would otherwise be a very boring course, very interesting!
This is a class that teaches you the building blocks of music which will help you with any music related degree, not just performance or education.
Loved it
I really enjoyed this course. The skills test helped me identify the intervals and stuff very fast so I don't have to count out the steps. It also went over canons and counterpoint.
I'm really glad that this course went more in-depth as to how to write counterpoint
As this is Theory I, things aren't particularly hard yet. The things we learned were at a pace that required no outside studying. Perfectly fine class.
The instructions were clear and the assignments were simple and straightforward as well.
I loved this course; Sean Yeh is the best. He's extremely knowledgeable and made the class enjoyable. However, he may not be able to properly get a point across every now and then.
This course is good at starting at the fundamentals and then expanding into other ideas. This adds another dimension to the music we play.
This course was adequate in increasing my knowledge of music theory.
I found the first few weeks to be way too easy, but later on it began to be a little bit more challenging. Even still, I would have liked the course to move faster through the material.
The class was well structured in a way that moved quickly enough, but also provided time to ask questions and absorb the material.
I love how much practice we do together

A highly student-orientated teaching approach is employed in this class. Concepts are taught, and students are given ample time to practice in class activities. There is also feedback given in class for homework and class assignments⾬tivities, which helps for the quick absorption of theory concepts. Because of that, students need not study extensively for class assessments, because the concepts are well-taught and drilled during class hours.
I really wanted to learn the "rules" of music, and this was perfect for that!
We learned about species counterpoint writing. The transition between topics are smooth and you don't need to spend a lot of time on it.
Several rules such as the note-to-note writing and factors of beautiful melodic lines are important for me to understand 16th century music better.

I loved this class. It was a very fair amount of work for a half credit class. Kenn is very engaging and seems to enjoy theory and teaching. At the beginning of the quarter, I was so bored with two voices and I didn't see any applications. But, once we got into 3 voices, things became more interesting and my compositions started to sound like music. I'm also just a theory nerd, so that's part of the reason I liked this class so much.

I truly loved all aspects of this class. The inside and outside of class work was very doable yet challenging. The projects and compositions or fun and I felt that I learned a lot from doing them. I was surprised by the depth of the quality of education at the professor provided.

Kenn Kumpf makes this counterpoint something that I legitimately wanted to learn more about, and he presents the material in a fun and interesting way. He is clearly committed to this class, and it's almost hard to imagine him doing anything else.
This course was a challenge but a lot of fun.
Although theory isn't my favorite class, I have learned to appreciate it and had lots of fun writing my own compositions.
I felt satisfied to learn counterpoint because I feel that it did have significance in my interpretation of music
Really fun and interesting difficult but well explained
Wouldn't be good if not very interested because of all the work but if are then really enjoy
good instructor. hope he could emphasize more on what's important and what's not. sometimes the lines are pretty blurry
Learn how to do counterpoint and get good at it!
Rosenberg is very knowledgeable and an engaging lecturer. He tells you exactly what he wants on exams and papers. Also he wants everyone to succeed

Rosenberg is a very good lecturer - he manages to captivate his students with his calm voice and extraordinary demonstrations of concepts at the piano. I enjoyed the topics of his class very much, and feel that this will probable be the most lax course out of the music history sequence.

This class was one of the least stimulating course I have taken at Northwestern. Prof. Rosenberg's lectures were often filled with self-serving intellectual questionings without any clear point or drawn historical narrative.

Unfortunately, I did not find that I was introduced to many new topics in this course -- it focused mainly on repertoire, and I was already familiar with the majority of what was covered. I wish that the course had focused more on compositional trends and historical events that occurred during the period.
Professor Rosenberg is excellent! Workload is very light and grading system is fair.
When Rosenberg talks, I enter another dimension. Stingy with the lecture notes though.
Rosenberg is an utterly lovely man. He provides a very fresh spin on historical concepts and always entertains as well as educates.

Filled with asinine assessments designed to test how well you can memorize and promptly forget information. Deeply irritating grading policies (eg. taking 10% off of virtually everyone in the class for double spacing an assignment where we were not told to single space), and not enough depth in any of the content to actually be interesting.
I felt that I learned very little in this course. The fact that we were quizzed on things like Chicago Citations and Musical Catalogues didn't help at all.

Professor Rosenberg is definitely a great professor. Of course, the material itself is pretty dry and boring, but he makes the class bearable. The grade distribution is pretty clear, and it's definitely an almost guaranteed A- or A if you study for the quizzes. He gives you what to study for the quizzes, so make sure you study those. The worst part of this entire course is the final research paper which is 8-10 pages. Unfortunately, we didn't really get any guidance on the paper. It's only worth 15% of our grade, but still, it would have been nice to have a bit more guidance on choosing our topics or for research. The final is take-home, and you can pretty much answer all of the questions as long as you do some of the readings and pay marginal attention in class.
Very manageable course - the more notes you take in class the easier the assignments will be.

This class wasn't bad - take it with Rosenberg instead of new Talle if you want less work. Rosenbeg is a gem and he really tells a story in his lectures. He is understanding and not too demanding. But the TA..... don't even get me started. She is obsessed with having the class pass around a written attendance sheet (already this idea is very "high school") and honestly this interrupts the class so much as people have to stand up to pass it around and then eventualy pass the sheet back to her. What year are we in? There are plenty of online attendance websites.
Take with Rosenberg!! Minimal work + engaging lectures.

On the final he picked out some very specific details from lecture (I take detailed notes generally and even I didn't have some of them) so might be good to be aware of that. I managed fine with the internet's help, though (it's a take home)
Easiest class you will take in bienen in the worst way
music of the long 18th century
This class was a good mix of relaxed, manageable assignments with stimulating, interesting lecture
The professor is not very specific about when he is going on a tangent and when he is talking about information that is in the curriculum. It can be confusing
The course accomplished everything it possibly could have for a 10 week course covering a huge section of Western music history.

Rosenberg often has interesting things to say in lecture, but his delivery isn't very exciting. Some people listen intently, and some people can't stay awake while he's talking. His lectures flow well, but he often spends a lot of time saying redundant or unnecessary things.
This course was SO dry. It was difficult for me to connect to⿞velop any interest in the course content.

Professor Rosenberg is super approachable and responsive to emails. The class consists of short quizzes, short writing assignments, one research paper, and a take-home final. The work is not overwhelming as long as you start early enough on the research paper.
The class is very structured so I really liked it. There are weekly listening quiz which can get VERY HARD.
It was really nice to have all the lectures so organized and easy for me to follow. Studying for assessments was pretty straightforward thanks to Professor Talle.
It was ok
Good course; Talle did a good job condensing two centuries into one quarter. The readings and listenings are well-organized and make sense, there are just so many of them. Lectures were great
Great professor, very interesting lectures.

This definitely felt like the first year Talle taught this class (there were more than a few kinks) but he is a really great lecturer and picks interesting topics to discuss. Definitely worth taking over the other teacher.

I really enjoyed this class although there is a lot of work to do. I learned a lot in this class and I enjoyed the lecture overall. It is very interesting to see how pieces that are equally famous during the time ends up differently now. Just make sure you don't fall behind on the reading.

I would have liked to focus more on instrumental music rather than opera, since we did a lot of opera. I was mostly interested in the stories and the lives of the composers we come across all the time in our industries, but I found myself most concerned with the listening quizzes. I did learn a lot from listening, even with the overwhelming amount we had to do, but I still would have liked to learn more about the historical influences on certain instrumental composers.
Professor Talle is an extremely passionate teacher, always trying to engage students through added humor and tangents. He truly cares about them and is always trying to improve the class structure
Expect a listening and analysis course not a history course.

The amount of reading and listening really is a lot, but the work you are putting in really does help you learn. If you do not put in the time, however, it is really easy to fall behind and get bad grades on quizzes. Everything that appears on quizzes and tests are things that we clearly went over or were indicated that they are things we should know about. No surprises.

This course emphasizes lifestyle techniques that will help in movement, being stationary, and in any activity we pursue. The unnecessary tensions are recognized and we learn to "let go" of those tensions, bringing our body into a more correct alignment for more effective function. This technique is also helpful for performing.
Very low key but also didn't learn anything that helped me improve my performance which is disappointing.
How to practice more efficiently and how to know your body more in achieving it.

I noticed some improvement in my sense of pitch and intonation, but I felt the course was very unstructured. There were no clearly defined units or skills we were working on, and each class seemed to be a random assortment of exercises. It would be nice to have clearly defined objectives and skills so that the exercises we did in class were directly applicable to material included on the examinations.

Because learning something like aural skills just requires practice, class time was often a drag, since concepts would just be repeated. At the same time, however, the concepts can be difficult to actually learn. The class setting is simply not conducive to the subject, although there is likely no better way. Any progress I made was mainly through individual instruction.
Niki is very disorganized and ineffective as a teacher. She is a nice person though

This course is clearly a well-established and organized class on the whole and the assignments and performance videos were usually challenging but helpful. However my teacher was extremely unqualified to teach this class. She often complained of getting little sleep and being stressed out by her own work - this inability to balance her own life led to her being extremely disorganized during class and she would constantly be unable to play diction examples correctly or consistently for us, leading to a lot of confusion. As long as you have a good TA this class is excellent - despite having a disorganized teacher I still learned and improved my solfege singing and aural skills a great deal just through all the exercises we do in class every day.
I really don't understand why the voice majors aren't in a separate aural skills class.
I know I learned because I have a much better ear now, but the class felt pretty repetitive. I know repetition is necessary in ear training, but it was hard to stay interested.

It wasn't the most pleasant of courses; not particularly organized and not particularly engaging. The work was necessary and I feel that my ear improved over the quarter, but not in the most efficient of ways.
It was fine. This class is a necessary evil, and the department makes it bearable. I do wish theyɽ tie the exercises to real-world situations,though.
learned a lot! but was also super challenging. had lots of spots where I didn't know how to figure out by myself but the student teachers also gave tutoring sessions to help out
Aural skills is sort of a necessary evil-- although I enjoyed it, it doesn't come naturally for everyone and can involve a bit of outside preparation for the performance checks.

This section (With Arrellin) started out as extremely frustrating. He was unclear on instructions and expectations, and the class itself was boring. However, as the quarter got on and the material got more difficult, it was clear that I had improved a lot to handle the new material. Arrellin isn't a great teacher but he is a nice guy, and a lot better than some of the other aural skills TAs from what I've heard. I always felt underprepared for performance checks, and in order to prepare myself I had to practice out of class, which he didn't necessarily give us tools on how to do.

Made Aural skills an approachable subject. Definitely study outside of class though if you really want to improve. Some of the material presented in class is easier than what comes up on the test. Never thought I would be where I am. Aural Skills!!!
It's really a necessary subject
Rhythm way way easier than dictation and the like wish former moved faster and latter slower so annoying but just me I realize
I am a better at aural skills because of this course.
It was challenging in that it is difficult to improve if you are inherently a bad singer.
I wanted to get better at ear training, and being able to hear songs and transcribe them, both of which I have definitely improved upon!
Extremely difficult.

This course is very useful for anyone who plans to remain involved with music in the future. Whether you are a member of a symphony orchestra or the backing band for a pop singer, the ability to hear melodies and then play them on your instrument is invaluable, and this course teaches you how to do exactly that.
This course has helped me improve my abilities to apply my ear training to my instrument.
It's a necessary evil and not the most fun, but Hudson makes it more than bearable. Great teacher!
I really do not like this class, Mr. Hudson is a really nice guy but the class sucks, I can't sing and I don't know solfege well enough to get by
This course really helped to improve all of my aural skills. Andy is a really fantastic teacher and is very willing to take time to help people improve.
The course has demonstrated the being a musician isn't only about how well you play your instrument, but also how well your listening skills are.
I thought this course was very good, and taught well by a TA that was very engaged in the material and helping the students learn.
Very hard
I enjoyed it a lot because it was very helpful.
This class helped keep my aural skills in check. We were always working on sight-reading, dictation, and learning concepts that are sometimes mentioned in theory.

I learned a lot and this course covered a lot of material. I appreciate the practice materials posted on canvas, but I think much more practice was needed for my skills to be up to par for the exams. I also feel that there should be some sort of cumulative guide outlining what we should know. This has been provided for music theory exams in the past and I find it so helpful because aural skills has gone on for so many quarters up until this point that it is genuinely hard to keep track.

This class decreased my sight-singing abilities in terms of just being able to produce the pitch of the notes on the page. Before I took it, I was able to sight sing anything using perfect pitch, but thinking of solfege, modulation, and intervalic melodies messed with my skills. It is not by any means my TA's doing since she was just teaching the course, but the course structure must be re-done from the foundation.
Alex makes the class interesting.
I think it's either you get it or don't. But with hard work anyone can probably do well, and there is always support.
It was ok
very useful course, but I'm bitter that my grade is so low even though I put in so much time into this half credit class. Very glad I am in this, but I wish Carter was more lenient with grading
Not a bad class as long as you don't take with Liza. While she is a very sweet person, her teaching made this class a much more frustrating experience than it needed to be.

She had trouble explaining theory concepts and often didn't realize she made a mistake (for example, teaching a misspelled chord) until someone points it out. She often would not correct the class when we sing a wrong note while arpeggiating a chord or sight-singing unless someone questions it. She regularly messed up chords in the harmonic dictations and would have to restart each play-through. She had a hard time keeping tempo while playing melodic and rhythmic dictations on the piano. This was so bad on the final that even though she gave us 2 extra listens on top of the normal 6 times, most if not all of the class still had no idea where each measure began and what rhythm she was attempting to play. Even though she was very nice and very accommodating about performance check times, it was still an extremely frustrating quarter.

This course does an adequate job of teaching the basic skills of what we're supposed to learn. I think it would be useful to just do more singing. I suppose sightsinging is very useful for me, and I would like more practice in singing complex harmonies and challenging aural examples.
Having aural skills is something I think is important for a musician but I don't think this class facilitates improving these skills well
It's fine. I can't say the class was especially engaging, but I learned what I needed to learn.
Dr. Carter is a nice man. Consistent and fair, and for the most part will not waste your time. Reinhart's curriculum is brutally ineffective, however.

Carter is much better than a lot of TAs but you have to be sure to go out of your way to find what you need to work on because a lot of class time could be better spent being in a practice room doing exercises by yourself, not in pairs
Good class with a lot of different activities to focus on improving skills.

Dr. Carter does a fine job of teaching a frustrating curriculum imposed by the department. We've now left the realm of usefulness and are into a land of frustration, angst, and overall monotony. We don't have a choice not to take this though, so what's there to say? I wish there was more sight singing in class.
This course is fine and you have to take it

I thought my teacher was great and responsive, he was very knowledgeable and cares a lot about his students' success in the course, but I am not entirely sure about how much this class is needed for me to succeed as a musician in the real world.
I found this course to be mostly challenging although I did not always feel intellectually challenged in class particularly. The homework and material itself was challenging enough.
I feel like I've gotten more adept at pitch identification and rhythmic and melodic dictations, however harmonic dictations are a dirty gnarly beast that can be skewered with a hot iron.

Some people are just naturally better at aural skills and its hard to catch up because you can't really control what you hear but there's a little part that you have control over like the prepared stuff and learning the possibilities of chord progressions
I loved the course, I learned a ton about the spanish language and culture. I'm still kinda shitty at spanish but it was fun regardless.

Professor Amorese was the best! We reviewed vocab and grammar during class in partner activities which was helpful in solidifying the grammar/vocab we learned from the homework assignments. We did have a quiz almost every week but I preferred that because it gave me a chance to review the information and also have more grades besides just the 2 tests, compositions, and homework.
The course was a good one, in which we tried to focus on speaking the language as the best way to learn it.
I really enjoyed the course and feel prepared to move to the next level.

I didn't expect to learn so much Spanish in such a short period of time, especially when I had never studied the language before. Classes do move very fast and its important to try and keep on top of vocabulary. Profesora Amorese is very enthusiastic and made coming to class enjoyable. However, I do feel that she is a pretty harsh grader compared to what my friends have said about their professors in other 101 classes.

I was not looking forward to taking Spanish, but the class was still somewhat interesting because we didn't purely focus on vocab and grammar. Sometimes the homework assignments felt more like busy work, but most of them helped me be prepared for class and understand the material.

First, this course is very good and I would highly recommend it to a new Spanish student. If you have any Spanish background however, it will probably be all review. Professor Amorese is very passionate about Spanish and is very good at communicating ideas, assigning relevant work, and designing tests that assess acquired skills. Quizes are frequent, but helpful in keeping the whole class at the same level.
It's a lot of learning Spanish outside of class and sometimes it does get very frustrating. But professor Amorese is extremely understanding and is a great teacher with a lot of enthusiasm.
I loved this course!

This was overall a great course. It was very introductory, but that was helpful to me since I had never taken Spanish before. The workload wasn't too much, but it was just enough for me to feel like I was actually learning valuable language skills. If you are at all considering learning Spanish, take this class, and take it with Amorese!

This course required a lot of small assignments outside of class because we spent most of class speaking. We also took several quizzes throughout the quarter. We covered a lot of content in a short amount of time. It was a lot of work, but we really learned a lot. If you can, take this course with Professor Amorese. She is a tough grader, but she is very enthusiastic and made the class more fun!
I really enjoyed this course because it wasn't too challenging, but we learned a lot.

This was a great introductory course for starting out in the Spanish language! Professor Amorese was energetic and very helpful when any material was confusing. As long as you stay on top of the homework and take time to practice the vocabulary and grammar concepts, this class was not too hard.

I enjoyed this course a lot. Professor Colom-Mena was witty and fun to talk with. He was really good at leading the discussion in class and gave us helpful worksheets that really boosted our knowledge while also giving us cultural information. What I did not like was the Pearson MySpanishLab work, which felt like a waste of time. It was not helpful at all in my mastering of material. Professor Colom-Mena was not a fan of it either, but we had to do it, because the Spanish department makes us. Buying the access code feels like a waste of $150.
The teacher is very knowledgeable of the language, so he taught without the book most of the time, which helped the class learn more.

I adored this course because of the fact that my professor, Joel Colom-Mena, structured the class to be very conversation oriented. I feel as though I am leaving with a comfort with speaking Spanish beyond that of a beginner.
Study regularly.
It was good.
I loved this class. It was great because the professor created an environment that got all students excited about Spanish and made us learn the language rather than reading from a book.
I loved taking this course. If you can take it with Professor Colom please do! He was an amazing instructor.

This was my favorite class of the quarter and the only class that did not fill me with crippling dread and depression when I thought about it. It helps that I am taking Spanish because I want to and not as a language requirement, but this was an incredible experience.

Spanish.course_name: SPANISH_199-0_26: Lang in Context: Contemp Spain
comments: This was a fantastic course! You learn so much about Spanish history, culture, and contemporary life. The course material was very engaging and thorough, as it's a combination of modules, articles, short videos, and films. The class was very comprehensive. We discussed course material, but also had plentiful conversations and debates comparing Spain to the U.S. Reyes is a fantastic instructor who deeply cares about the subject, and she knows how to engage the class.The best part of the course are the mesas redondas. These are discussions with 4-5 classmates about the films you watch for the course (there are 2). This was a great way to practice speaking skills in a relaxed environment.

You'll learn a lot about Spanish history and present-day issues in the country; be prepared to speak Spanish constantly and not care if you mess up! Reyes is a fun, theatrical and encouraging professor who really wants you to succeed. The class itself is pretty easy; make sure to do the homework or you'll let your classmates down. There's no place to hide if you don't know what you're talking about.
There was a lot of busy-work to do at home, but class was very interesting and engaging.
I liked this class a lot. Didn't focus on the language or grammar of spanish very much but learned a lot of interesting stuff about Spain as a country
It was an excellent style for learning a language. Very engaging and participation based. The class had a surprising amount of homework, more than I expected.

Really fun course! Not too hard, as the only work is to read the book. Tests weren't too bad, just focus on the passages discussed in class. The professor is really knowledgeable on the book. Class got dry at times since it really is just the professor lecturing for 50 minutes, and attendance is mandatory, but it's not hard at all.

Professor Fernandez-Morera has a lot of knowledge on the content and DQ itself is a very interesting/humorous read. But because the class is highly reading based, it becomes very stressful if you fall behind on readings, which is easy to happen after the first midterm when the readings pick up. I would take this class if you have some time in your schedule. Overall a good class.

This course is a good lesson in time-management! You only need one 1000+ page book for this class. There's a midterm, a final, and weekly discussion sections. We were allowed to take home the essay portion of the final and complete quick quote identification during the exam time. Lecture is fine. It can be a little early for some (10am) and the professor speaks softly, so you might lose focus easily, but other than that, two thumbs up. Don Quixote is extremely interesting and an easy read. Be sure to keep up with the reading guide or be ahead. It's too easy to skip one day and end up falling behind.
i really liked the book, and the class is totally manageable.
This class provided an overview of Don Quixote and several possible interpretations.
I felt like the material and professor were really interesting but the way the class was taught didn’t really reflect that.
reading. so much.

I was really eager to come in and learn further about a book that I've known and loved for so long, but there seemed to be little to no enthusiasm from the other students, and sometimes the professor himself.

TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! this class is perfect: EASY and INTERESTING. I've always wanted to read Don Quixote because its a classic and everyone should read it, but i know that if i tried to read it on my own i wouldn't have appreciated it as much as i do now that I've been taught Don Quixote in a class setting. this class is super easy and low key, only homework is reading Don Quixote and there is 1 easy midterm and a final that is mostly take home. it's clear that the professor is passionate about Cervantes' works and Don Quixote, but he is a little hard to understand. you have to go to class to succeed.

GREAT class! The professor is really enthusiastic about Don Quixote and I love the book because of his insight. If you ever thought about reading Don Quixote, I would STRONGLY recommend this class because it will illuminate way more than you might have picked up on just reading by yourself.

The class discussions and lectures were informative but rather dry. If you want to specifically learn about Cervantes and Don Quijote, then this is a great class, but if you are looking for a distro and have no prior interest in Don Quijote, you may want to look elsewhere.

Spanish.course_name: Intro to Latina/o Literature,Intro Latina/o Literature,Introduction to Latina/o Lit
Spanish.instructor: ENGLISH_277-0_20: Intro to Latina/o Literature,LATINO_277-0_1: Intro Latina/o Literature,SPANISH_277-0_1: Introduction to Latina/o Lit
comments: Great lit class if you're interested in Latino Studies. I really enjoyed all of the pieces that were chosen for this class which helped understand latinos in the US and latino literature as a literary cannon.

This class is really easy, at least the way Professor Aparicio teaches it a lot of the books are repetitive, and kind of about the same thing. TA Maria is really great, she writes extensive commentary on all of the short papers, does her best to hand these back in a timely fashion so we can apply her notes to are next paper and is a really fair grader. I think a big problem I had with Professor Aparicio was that she didn't really create an environment where people were comfortable to share their reactions to the material, especially not students who were non-Latino˺. Sometimes she would respond to non-Latino˺ students' comments as though to suggest that they were not warranted to make observations about this literature, or that they were generalizing. Of course these kinds of comments are going to be generalizations; it is understood even of social science research that because it requires the compilation of several specific and variant cases into one analyses, the conclusions drawn are generalizations, and can contradict personal experience. I also think its inappropriate to call out specific students in the class for being Latino˺, it really divides the class into people who have "a right" to speak on behalf of the Latinx community and the people who do not, and who therefore should not be commenting on Latino˺ literature. And then she wonders why nobody speaks up in class.

I really enjoyed professor Aparicio's teaching style. She is very accessible to students and allows many interpretations of the text in class discussions. The timing of assignments is not ideal. We did not have a lengthy writing assignment until week 5 and then three more jammed in the last three weeks of the class followed by the final. In general, though, this is a great course, very interesting material, and not overly demanding.

Take this class! I loved it. Did a lot of group work, but the readings were so manageable and so interesting. Aparicio wants to know how you feel about the readings so speak up. Only thing I did not like was how we had Canvas posts due the morning before class day, so definitely no procrastinating allowed.
This is a great class to take. The work load is light however I did wish there was more group discussion so that the class doesn't get boring.

Overall a great course. I was disappointed by a lack of classroom engagement at first, but it didn't take aware from the course material, which was fantastic. Aparicio is an amazing professor and she makes each class enjoyable.

Amazing class. Loved the readings, the professor, and the discussions. Readings are pretty easy to keep up with and are often really interesting to read. Only four 2 page essays, weekly discussion prompts, and a final paper, so it was very manageable.
This was a great course. All of the texts were interesting and Aparicio did a great job of pointing out the most important ideas of every text.
class is not too hard, 4 essays and one final essay 8-10 pages, try to participate in class or you will lose a lot of points, can only miss class twice

I really enjoyed this class! As a Spanish major, I will say I didn't know before that THIS CLASS IS TAUGHT IN ENGLISH! Regardless, we talked a lot about the latino˺/x experience in the US and the stereotypes, myths, and realities associated with that experience. All of the poetry and novels we read were actually really interesting and enjoyable to read. We had responses to the reading due at 9 AM the days before class, which was sometimes stressful but nice because it forces you to get the homework done a few days before class. We had around four 1-2 page papers, where you analyzed the text and a final 8-10 page paper. IF YOU ARE A SPANISH MAJOR, and NOT a native Spanish speaker, it's definitely difficult to translate the discussions you have in class into a paper because apart from the responses all of your essays have to be in Spanish. Just be aware it's very doable but was definitely more difficult
this class was super interesting and made me think a lot more about latinidad and what i means. i liked almost all of the texts that professor aparicio picked.

The lecture was great and really stimulating. I enjoyed reading the texts because they were all very eye opening and offered a different aspect of Latino history. Even if you're not Latino you should take this course because it offers a better understanding of how Latinos have been treated in the U.S., and how literature has been affected.

This was a fun and interesting course, but I felt that the prompts for the papers, which are 10% of your grade each, could have been a lot more specific and that the grading on them was a bit hard to follow, as in sometimes it felt like there was an answer that was expected.
I didn't learn much in the class, and it was really unorganized. Prof Fernandez-Morera is fun, but I felt lost in his class the entire time, which made the final presentation really difficult.

This class was very disorganized, and I'm not sure what I learned from it. Fernandez-Morera is a nice man, but this class was unpredictable. We had no idea when we would be giving presentations and received little feedback on the work we did do. He is extremely knowledgeable about the topic of medieval Iberia, and I wish I could have learned more in this class.
We didn't exactly stick to the syllabus, and the course was pretty dull at times, but overall it was relatively easy and pushed me to think in new ways about ancient texts.

The material is interesting but the class is pretty disorganized and we fell super far behind schedule. Final presentation (25% of grade) and final paper (50% of grade) topics are assigned by the professor but there's still a good amount of flexibility in what direction you want to take with those, and the shorter response papers are pretty open-ended and you can choose something that interests you.

Fernandez-Morera is the best professor I've had at Northwestern. There are various response papers˿ive minute orals based on the readings. Then, you are assigned a subject for a 20 minute presentation and 8 page paper. Those are the only real assignments of the quarters.
Overall, the assignments are pretty straightforward, this class is bound to fall behind
Interesting course, your grade will be based on 3-5 5 min oral response, a 20 min oral report, and a paper in the end.

Pretty laid-back course. The majority of the class is student-run through presentations and the like, which can be good or bad. The class lost focus midway through the course and struggled to stay on schedule. The final paper still gave an opportunity to examine a topic in-depth, which was nice. Dario F-M is wonderful as always, but he could have done more lecturing in the later stages of the class to keep things more focused.

Pretty disorganized course. Primarily student presentations, I wish Professor Fernandez-Morera would have lectured more because that's when the class was at it's strongest. Oh well, still very little work and the subject matter is interesting if you like history.
stewart adams. that is all. he is the man. do not take this course with anybody else. he is amazing.

The final exam was very grammar heavy which was upsetting considering the lack of grammar we had learned through the course. Adams prepares us well when it comes to discussing the stories and movies we see.
This is a very fun low stress course. Almost no homework. As long as you attended class concepts were not difficult.
Prof Adams is the best guy ever. Hilarious, entertaining and just a world class kind of guy. If you can take a class with him, do it
Take Spanish with Adams! He is so chill and makes the class easier. There are a few quizzes, two exams, and a presentation. Not really any homework. Definitely recommend for an easy Spanish class.
This class was cool because you learned through movies and stories!
Adams is one of my favorite professors, he has so much knowledge and teaches the class extremely well.
This class was not difficult. Lots of movies to watch and the course focused on controversial topics rather than becoming a better speaker or writer.

I really enjoyed this course. All of the readings, movies, and other resources we used were very interesting and allowed for us to talk about popular topics in the world today in a Spanish context. Professor Adams is an awesome professor.
This course was challenging for me, especially the grammar aspects. However, there are lots of opportunities for points, so if you do poorly on an assignment, there are chances to make up for it.
Good class and professor. However, if you are reluctantly taking the class, due to the WCAS foreign language requirement, it will not be particularly interesting.

This is a relatively easy course. Rifka is a great teacher and she cares about her students so much. At times, the homework can feel like busy work, but overall the work level is fairly low. The in class activities are usually very fun as well.

This course was a good course to solidify basic Spanish skills to be able to read, write, and speak the language effectively. The course was structured in a way that allowed students to get what they put into it but it was not necessarily challenging. Sometimes the homework or requirements on projects were unclear, but Rifka was really good at helping students who reached out her with any questions.
The class was great. I would definitely recommend taking it.
While the movies that were required to watch in order to score well on exams and complete homework were not always the most interesting, Rifka made sure that classes were interesting and engaging.

This course was incredible. Rifka has the biggest heart of anyone I've ever met and she is devoted to making sure you genuinely learn. The class itself was also not too bad, as long as you watch the movies she assigns and understand them, you're looking at a solid grade, probably an A. Just talk in class and talk to Rifka! She'll love it.
It was refreshing to learn about Spanish literature and film in the class, which otherwise I would not have been exposed to.
Good class, fairly easy, but there is a lot of homework and it is time consuming. Asha is a great professor, she's really patient and takes her time explaining what we don't understand.

This course is a lot of work, especially with Profesora Nagaraj. She assigns two hour long movies during the week, and often assigns several hours worth of readings and worksheets even as she expresses concern about our stress levels. She grades very harshly- I don't believe it is possible to get an A without perfect use of accent marks. Expectations are unclear for most of the written work, but all of the conversational parts of class are very helpful. Even though I hated this class, I am more fluent than I was at the start.

Asha is amazing! I’m so happy I took this class with her. I liked that we broke into small groups to discuss and put what we’ve learned in practice. I liked that we discussed movies and poems, as well as important social issues. Asha made class very fun and comfortable
I thought the course was well designed in its use of movies to keep the class engaged. I highly recommend continuing this in the future.

I enjoyed the course and how small the class size was. There was a lot of homework, and, at times, I felt that the homework was tedious and/or unnecessary. Prior to taking this course, I had not planned to continue taking Spanish after freshman year of college which influenced my feeling that the homework was tedious.

Well-taught course. Asha is a very kind, patient teacher and seems to genuinely care if you succeed. Keep in mind that you will watch some movies, but otherwise, the homework is pretty chill. In-class group work felt forced and painful to me, but other aspects of the course were fine. Also, the textbook is exorbitantly overpriced imo, and I wish we didn't have to purchase it.
I was a bit worried about how well Iɽ do in a class where Iɽ have to work with spoken Spanish a lot, but the class proved to be very manageable.
Movies were long but fairly compelling. I think it would be better for teaching Spanish if Prof. Adams spoke more Spanish but it did help at times that he spoke about the movies in English.
My main concern with spanish is to become fluent eventually. this course helped me to move closer to my goal.

Prof. Adams is a genuinely nice guy and a fairly easy grader, so if you are taking 125 to fill language requirement, definitely take it with Adams. But if you are trying to actually learn Spanish, I would recommend somebody else. If you remember Spanish from high school, you don't really need to study more than the required assignment, which is, to be honest, annoying sometimes.

It's very easy to get a high grade, with a little bit of effort. I went into the midterm and final with 30 minutes of studying beforehand, and still managed to get above a 95%. It's worth the investment to get the textbook, but the optional grammar booklet is unnecessary if you can utilize online resources. Points were fairly well-spread, from discussion, homework, tests, and writing assessments. Homework load is quite low, and syllabus clearly says the dates in which these assignments are due.
I think the course was relatively easy, and not too much work at all.

This is a course based around reading and watching spanish movies. While there is a review element for grammar, be prepared to spend a decent amount of time reading poems and watching films. Before going into this one should have a strong foundation of the basics of the language

If this class is a requirement for you, like most people, TAKE IT WITH THIS PROFESSOR. He's awesome. Very low-stress, only engaged in interesting, useful conversations about culture in Spanish-speaking countries. No pointless worksheets.

I don't think 125 was the best Spanish class I've taken, nor do I think I'm going to continue with Spanish, but it was a good course to cap things off. Overall pretty chill, except for that they expect you to watch five full movies, which isn't too feasible for a college student.

Professor Adams is the best! Easily the best Spanish professor I have had at Northwestern. He is incredibly relaxed and low key while simultaneously stimulating interesting and effective discussion during class periods. He doesn't inundate you with busy work and instead focuses on the topics that actually matter. Definitely take this class with Adams!

To be successful in this course, you'll need to have a strong memory about the movies you watch and the literature you read. While this is not impossible for every students, students who are concerned about getting every possible point will not be successful in this course.
This was a great class! Profa Teresa is a wonderful professor.
Good continuing spanish class if you want to review high school and ensure you're prepared for college level classes
A lot of work outside of class but it was good practice

The course is a lot of work, including watching movies and reading stories/poems. There's online homework and writing homework along with the reading and watching. The stories and movies were difficult to understand but the discussions afterwards in class helped us to better understand the material. The discussions in class were often interesting and the professor was good at facilitating them. The homework was manageable and the tests weren't very difficult as long as you studied.

This was a fun class. I feel like I definitely improved my Spanish speaking abilities, and the exams and quizzes really force you to learn the new grammar points. Watching and discussing movies was fun though some were very long. Super site is helpful for learning the vocab and practicing the grammar. Professor Villanueva is really fun, laid back and nice. Overall I enjoyed this course.
The movies and readings were difficult to understand, but review in class made them manageable.

This course helped me improve on my Spanish language skills. I learned a lot of new material that I never learned before. There are a lot of homework assignments, but they help prepare for the quizzes and exams.
this class can be a bit boring sometimes if you're already good with grammar, but you can learn a lot about Hispanic culture. there are lots of great in-class activities too
This class will help you improve your speaking and writing skills.
Teresa is not too hard and I had a fun class group which made taking a Spanish class (something I didn't want to do) a more enjoyable experience.
Challenging and fast-paced. However, if you have some background in Spanish and are a good learner, it's manageable as long as you stay on top of grammar.
The class was appropriately interesting, and Asha worked very hard to motivate people to participate. The movies could be very long for one night of homework.

Good course, good balance of speaking and reading/writing. Learning focussed on reading and going over grammar issues that higher level spanish students typically struggle with, so very useful material.
A fast-paced review of grammar coupled with movies and some reading. Great for reviewing Spanish grammar and learning the structures that will be expected in more advanced Spanish classes.
Not too much work and I liked that I only needed to take one quarter to fill my foreign language requirement

Nagaraj is very knowledgeable and passionate, but she is a very harsh grader. The class focuses nearly completely on audiovisual materials like movies or texts and poems. It is helpful and immersive, but the grammar lessons are often rushed and pushed to the side. The homework is mostly online through an online course (this means you have to purchase books new...) It's mainly multiple choice or true⿺lse which can be problematic for subjective questions.
This class was not as hard as it seems. Of course, it requires a decent amount of work and studying, but if your Spanish skills are good, then it's fine.
I really had a good time in this course, the instructor was great and the movies˺rticles we watched/read helped to apply the information we went over in class.
Good class, rough if no one participates in the discussion.

Spanish.course_name: SPANISH_261-0_21: Lit in Latin Am since 1888
comments: This is a good class to take for Spanish major/minors. You have 3 papers to write throughout the quarter and they are not long and you get great feedback on them. There are readings before every class; make sure you read and go to class prepared to discuss them as your grade heavily depends on it.

The readings for this class were often very difficult and took a very long time to read and understand. Class discussions were very helpful in understanding, but they could also be very stressful if you didn't fully understand the readings and therefore did not have very insightful things to say about the text. However, I enjoyed many of the texts that we read, and thought that discussions were interesting. The papers were kind of difficult to write, but they really helped me improve my literary analysis and Spanish writing skills.

Pretty interesting class. I found discussions to be intimidating sometimes, especially because some readings were difficult and Nathalie is not afraid to tell you if she disagrees with your interpretation. But overall, got to read some interesting literature, and Nathalie does a good job of tying in different contexts to the readings.

of all the professors for Spanish 250𯉑𯉠𯉡, Nathalie is the best. take literature with her. she is challenging and expects a lot but males class enjoyable. Participation is a large portion of the grade, which, if you do readings and pay attention in class is really beneficial. Nathalie is really helpful and understanding.
Literature courses aren't my favorite, but the professor was really nice and some of the readings were interesting, so a good class.
It is a hard and time consuming class, but my reading comprehension improved a lot.
it was fairly easy and did not require too much out of me. it really helps you work on your writing skills

I thought the course was excellent with helping me gain the vocabulary to explain and critique parts of the literature that we were reading. The length of the papers also helped me slowly get used to writing analysis about poems or short stories without it seeming too daunting,

Spanish.course_name: SPANISH_261-0_1: Lit in Latin Am since 1888
comments: Okay class, interesting readings, not super well organized, essays not very interesting, class could be boring at times, but manageable workload

Spanish.course_name: SPANISH_261-0_1: Lit in Latin Am since 1888
comments: Professor Coronado is great! He really cares about seeing you enjoy(/)understand the material and also improve your writing. I felt this quarter my Spanish (vocab and writing) improved more than any other quarter I've been at Northwestern. He's also lovely to talk to in office hours. The quizzes are definitely tricky, not really worth a lot though. I'll miss Wheezy (his dog), well and him too

It was a good class. It was fun at times. Professor would take his dog; it was great. Material is pretty interesting. Material consisted of short stories and poems. Professor understands we might not understand something so he helps us go through it during class.
This is a great class. Every topic discussed opened my eyes to other realities I was not aware of. The work load is manageable allowing yourself to focus on your other classes.
This class was really interesting!
Prof. Coronado is enthusiastic and really wants students to participate and be interested in class. Sometimes the readings were overwhelming but I really enjoyed the class.

Would HIGHLY recommend taking this course! Dr. Coronado is one of my favorite professors at NU. The paper assignments aren't difficult, and going to office hours is really helpful to think through your thesis. I liked a lot of the selected readings, especially those on magic realism. You're not expected to understand what readings mean going into class, as long as you understand the storyline. Dr. Coronado does a good job of making sure we understand what's going on. The quizzes focus on details you may not pick up on when reading a language that's not your first (even if they are more story-line type and not deeper meaning), so be sure to read a couple of times!

The class was straight-forward and engaging, and the texts were interesting. Prof. Coronado is really helpful if you go in for extra help, and his expectations for essays are clear. I learned a lot and enjoyed it.
Reyes was the sweetest and made the class always so so exciting. It was a thrill to be in that class even though some people really did not want to speak spanish.

Super fun class. Reyes is an awesome teacher who genuinely cares about improving your abilities as a spanish speaker. Enjoyed the strong emphasis on conversation, however, was slightly disappointed by how basic of grammar/vocab we covered.
Reyes is great and super sweet! Not a hard class and your Spanish improves a lot
Reyes is very sweet and understanding of other commitments, and really wants you to learn spanish. Pretty easy A if you're decent at spanish, an easy A... type
Prof. Reyes was very fun and enthusiastic, but I don't feel that I learned anything new this quarter
While I had no interest in the course material, the class was alright because. Reyes is a really fun and engaging teacher.

Reyes is incredibly excitable and enjoyable to spend class time with. It was easier than some other Spanish classes to fall behind slightly on material, but Reyes is so kind and fun and helps catch you up.

Way too much unhelpful busy work is assigned for this class. It takes hours to complete the weekly assignments, and then you need to dedicate even more time to teaching yourself the concepts outside of the assignment, because they are completely ineffective. There's also a huge vocab divide between students from 101 and kids who have taken 4 years of spanish in highschool. Students from 101 are expected to complete assignments and speak in class with way more vocabulary than the into class exposed them to.

It was good for being a required course, but didn't affect my interest in the Spanish language at all. Most of the time the activities were annoying to complete, especially the movies we had to watch outside of class. It was very much an introductory course meant to focus solely on the language and its rules.

I like how the assignments that determine your grade were spread out, no one set of quizzes˾xam can fail you. It was more holistic and allowed for you to shine even if you are not good at one type of assessment

I felt the class environment was very helpful to learning however you always need to pay attention and be prepared (or be good at winging it). There's some busy work sometimes but if you actually do it, it will help you in the long run. The video quizzes aren't so bad but the short videos in link with the book are so give yourself time to understand those. Overall, it's not a bad class as long as you put the effort in (which I suggest doing)!
This course was one of my favorites this quarter. I liked the focus on discussion in class, and I thought that the professor was great.
Lots of HW
The class taught a lot of grammar and vocabulary. A lot of the homework was completing worksheets and watching videos. It was a lot of good practice, but I wish we had gotten to speak more.

This class is fine if you have to take it to fulfill a requirement. Profesora Aubeneau is nice and is clearly passionate about making sure the students are able to hold conversations in consistent, correct Spanish. However, sometimes homework assignments are excessive and her grading is erratic. If you're an introvert, this class will definitely challenge you early on.

This is a traditional language class with frequent vocab and grammar quizzes and homework that takes around 30 minutes. Beyond that though I really enjoyed the discussions we had in this class and my Spanish speaking really improved because we did a lot of in class discussions. I really really enjoyed this class and it’s super super manageable
this is more accelerated then 115, but Nelia made it fun, she's a great teacher
its spanish. you learn spanish, its not too hard or stressful, just do the work and you'll be fine.

This class is a review of last year, and therefore you are expected to know a lot coming in. Nelida expected too much. I walked out of class feeling stupid instead of inspired because of her comments and corrections.

Typical Spanish course with lots of emphasis on speaking and listening. Most learning is done through the textbook, and class is mostly dedicated to practicing speaking and reviewing homework. Overall good experience with Aubeneau: fair grader, and does what she can to make class enjoyable given the constraints of the course.
Tests were fair, homework didn't take too long for the most part
The material is taught well, but there are too many extra assignments like watching Spanish movies and clips. Moves quickly enough.
I liked using the different medias to learn about cultural material
Requires more studying than 115 sequence.

Nelida is awesome! There is a larger component of participation in 121 than in 101, but the vocab and grammar is mostly a review. The book isn't as good this year and the videos can be a bit tedious and hard to understand
Aubeneau is a really great teacher and one of the nicest people, highly recommend taking this class with her.
This class was such a great class. The material was interesting and I feel more confident in my Spanish skills. The professor knew what she was doing! Great teacher, and a fun class!
Fine class, goes through the important topics of Spanish.

This class is pretty interesting and the workload is not bad. Part of the curriculum looks at the theory and make-up of different kinds of writing which is something I had never really thought about before. Baez is well-informed and cares about her students, and if you participate in class discussions you can get a lot out of them.

This course is amazing! Profesora Baez is so kind and insightful. She puts a lot of effort into giving students constructive feedback on their essays which helps immensely in turning in polished work. She genuinely cares about students understanding the readings that she assigns, and her enthusiasm for the material makes class discussions so enjoyable.

This class is really interesting, you get to study a variety of genres, authors, and time frames, giving you a good sampling of literature (which might also help you pick more specific class topics later on). The requirements for this are really manageable, do the readings (which aren't too time intensive), present once and write a couple essays. Ana Baez is a really great professor and she gets the class to contribute without pushing too hard, her feedback on essays, projects, and reading are also helpful.

A student COULD learn a lot from this course, if they so chose. This was a very "mature" class in that you got out of it as much as you put into it. Honestly – if worst came to worst – you could get by skipping a reading or too, but if you read them in depth & participated in class, you could also learn so much about both literature and the language.
Really great class with not too difficult of a workload. Profesora Baez is incredible, understanding, and knowledgeable.
I think the student presentations were very helpful.

Low-key frustrated that I bought the $60 textbook. The other book, which was $10 on Amazon, was actually just scanned to Canvas, so also not necessary. But all of the readings could have been found online, half of them were uploaded to Canvas and weren't even in the textbook anyway. I really think that all the readings should just be scanned, I only used the textbook once for a text that I couldn't find online. Aside from that, the class was great, incredibly similar to AP Spanish Lit. There were only five readings I didn't recognize having taken AP Lit. There were no exams, only three essays, two 4-pages and one 6-pages. They were all 20% of our grade, with a presentation also 20% and participation the final 20%. Most people got 10⼐ on the presentation, and the lowest anyone got on the papers was a 90, some with 100. Super easy A. Baez was super excited and really good at explaining the concepts to us.

The curriculum was phenomenal, the first spanish class ive taken at NU that centered content from latinamerica and especially the carribean. I wish that we had discussed some of the ideas further but I understand the limitations of the quarter system
Thought the readings were interesting and prof was really able to help us better understand them and stimulate interest.

This is a good introduction to Latin American (and some Spanish) literary texts. Baez covers a wide range of topics which is pretty ambitious for such a short class. Overall a good class to take as an intro to literary analysis and seminal Latin American texts.
